Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Equality, Well-Being and Leaving No One Behind
Outcome: People in the Caribbean equitably access and utilize universal, quality and shock-responsive, social protection, education, health, and care services
Output: 1.4. 17 BDS Crisis-affected populations in the Caribbean are able to meet their food, nutrition and other essential needs during and in the aftermath of shocks
Sub-Output: 2.4.17 BDS Affected populations benefit from strengthened¬†systems¬†to¬†deliver food, voucher and cash assistance
Description: WFP will assist shock-affected populations with cash-based transfers or food in-kind in response to events necessitating international assistance. This outcome focuses on meeting food, nutrition and other essential needs of shock-affected people
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: European Union; The Joint SDG Fund; United Nations World Food Programme; United States Agency for International Development Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance; World Food Programme Multi-donor
Implementation partners: Barbados Ministry of People Empowerment and Elder Affairs; Saint Lucia Ministry of Equity, Social Justice, and People's Empowerment; Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Ministry of National Mobilization, Social Development, Family, Gender Affairs, Youth, Housing and Informal Human Settlement; United Nations World Food Programme
SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.
Geography: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines; Barbados; Dominica; Saint Lucia
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2022 Narrative: In 2022, the UN continued to work with the Governments of Barbados, the Virgin Islands, and the OECS countries (Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Saint Lucia, and Dominica), in 2022, WFP provided cash , voucher or food assistance as part of governments‚Äô shock-responsive social protection programmes to assist vulnerable individuals affected by the severe socio-economic impact of COVID-19 and other shock-related events that occurred in the countries to meet the immediate nutritional and other essential needs of the vulnerable. In parallel with the provision of cash, voucher and food assistance support in the Virgin Islands (UK), Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Saint Lucia, Dominica and Barbados, WFP worked on strengthening national capacities for registration, vulnerability analysis, delivery mechanisms, monitoring and reconciliation of food, voucher and cash assistance and facilitated trainings in shock responsive social protection to improve the capacity of countries to respond to shock:Specifically, in Barbados, WFP provided technical assistance and guidance for targeting, verification and consolidation of the assistance recipients, and outreach, as well as human resources and technical expertise on logistics through its supply chain team and transportation assets by working together with the government to develop a distribution plan for social assistance. This support built on existing capacities and social protection systems utilized by the Government, further improving and strengthening ability to respond to shocks in the future. WFP also continued supporting the Government of Barbados to strengthen digital payment reconciliation processes, digital data collection and post-distribution monitoring by carrying out trainings for the Ministry of People Empowerment and Elder Affairs (MPEA) staff. 115 tablets were donated by WFP to the MPEA to further assist with these efforts.Furthermore, in Saint Lucia WFP developed and piloted a household vulnerability index aimed at informing response planning for shock-responsive social protection and overall social protection systems strengthening. The pilot tested the identification, targeting and delivery of social assistance to vulnerable persons affected by Hurricane Elsa and tested a new digital payment mechanism. The lessons learned from the pilot will inform the government‚Äôs efforts to strengthen social protection in response to shocks in Saint Lucia and across the Caribbean and to also expand Saint Lucia‚Äôs learning on how digital payments can be used to support the delivery of cash assistance to vulnerable persons before and after a shock.Additionally, In Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, WFP has provided technical support and guidance to the Government in the targeting, verification, and consolidation of the beneficiary list for WFP cash assistance and the World Bank's 6-month cash programme. The programme aims to assist approximately over 3,500 households affected by the volcanic eruption in 2021. WFP has engaged with the Ministry of National Mobilization in discussions to identify gaps in previous programmes, resulting in a technical agreement to strengthen the system to reduce poverty and vulnerability, increase resilience, and provide assistance to those affected by the shock that will be signed in 2023.With the establishment of the La Soufri√®re Relief Grant in 2021, the government was able to secure longer-term support for recipients through World Bank financing, with assistance extended for an additional six months. This was made possible by the improvements to the registration, verification, and vulnerability assessment processes, as well as ongoing monitoring, revision, and updating of the beneficiary list, which has increased the accuracy and accessibility of information through digitalization. WFP will continue to provide technical assistance in the delivery of cash assistance funded by the World Bank as the efforts shift back towards capacity building Lessons learned:-     Online channels should be considered for beneficiary registration, as manual forms can lead to inaccurate data collection with potential negative impact on provision of support to people in need. In addition, all requisite information for complete/comprehensive database of persons to be paid should be collected in a consolidated manner from the onset as participants can become difficult to reach which can impact the ability to create a database of beneficiaries-     The establishment of a data working group can be useful to foster coordination among different government ministries/entities. -     Where relevant, consider using a combination of payment modalities based on beneficiary preference.-     Strengthening the range of communication channels is essential to ensure that all beneficiaries are aware of what is being communicated and take swift action as necessary.
2023 Narrative: In 2023, WFP continued to work closely with governments within the region to strengthen social protection systems to respond to shocks. Progress has been made in strengthening critical areas of social protection systems such as data and information management, beneficiary targeting and delivery mechanisms to enable governments to better meet the needs of impacted populations in times of crisis in the following countries:  In Barbados, technical assistance was provided to the Ministry of People Empowerment and Elder Affairs to conceptualize and implement a research agenda on digital financial inclusion to explore the potential of digital payments for social protection. The joint research activity aims to provide the Government of Barbados with analysis on the current state of the digital financial ecosystem in Barbados with the view of exploring the use of digital payment modalities for improved social protection delivery and rapid scale-ups in emergencies. This support by WFP complements previous efforts since 2020 to strengthen social protection in Barbados and contributes to assisting the Government i transition towards a digital economy.  In collaboration with the Ministry of Equity in Saint Lucia, WFP is actively engaged in advancing digital payments for social protection.  Beginning with the successful testing of digital payments during an emergency in 2022, WFP brought together 61 beneficiaries of the Public Assistance Programme, as well as suppliers and government officials to solicit perspectives and insights into the use of digital payments for the delivery of assistance through social protection systems. The research also considers the use of digital finance options taking into consideration age, gender and geographic location, amongst other factors.  These efforts provide important information that can shape a more gender-responsive approach to strengthening social protection in the country.  Parallel to providing cash assistance to meet the nutritional needs of people impacted by the 2022 trough system in Dominica, systems strengthening support was provided to the government to improve targeting, delivery and verification capacities to enable the government to better meet the needs of the most vulnerable. WFP helped to improve how data from registration and verification processes would inform targeting and strategies for delivery of payments. Post distribution monitoring assistance was also provided to the government through training and focus group discussions with beneficiaries who received assistance under the Trough cash assistance programme. In the Virgin Islands (UK) WFP  partnered with the government to provide comprehensive technical assistance for the digitalization of the national social protection program, including the design and implementation of the new Public Assistance Programme (PAP).  WFP worked with  the Social Development Department (SDD) to conduct a thorough review of the services provided under the existing PAP, and its end-to-end process.  The review was able to identify weaknesses in the existing process and to identify the data and information needs along programmes cycles to move towards a more efficient and accountable process. A detailed Standard Operating Procedures to clarify roles, clarify definitions on targeting and supportive documentation needed etc. was developed and WFP provided technical support to create a first version of a digital system based on the review process with a flexibility built-in to allow for its adaptation to future regulation. This support consisted of the development, testing and improving of digital data collection tools at each step of the process, connected through a system of unique identifier for the client, and unique request number to track separately each request from intake to closure. An online database was designed, that pulls information automatically from the digital forms, making analysis easier, both for case management and for reporting purposes at a division level.  Client paper-based files are now digitized, allowing for easy access to the cases and reducing the volume of paper files.  In collaboration with the SDD team WFP facilitated trainings for different users of the system on the new process, their refined role, and the use of the tools. WFP also compiled user-guides for each role, that clearly describe in detail the step-by step process for managing cases through the system. The system was launched in February starting with registering new requests into the system and transitioning existing beneficiaries of the new PAP. Since the launch, improvements to the system were implemented along its development cycle, with WFP playing the role of facilitator between the SDD team and the Virgin Islands (UK) Health Services Authority. Developing the system in a relatively simple technical version first, enables the government to test the overall viability of the process, as its flexibility allows for rapid modifications of the system whenever weaknesses and solutions are identified. Once the system‚Äôs back-bone is tested and validated by all stakeholders, it can be used as the basis for the development of a proper software that will allow for more functionalities. The development of such software is a lengthy process, and the interim system will be used until that software is developed, tested and validated.   Lesson learned:  St Lucia  The feedback from the beneficiaries who took part in the focus group discussions indicated a preference for traditional payment modes. This underscores the significance of conducting thorough assessments of community attitudes and preferences before designing and implementing social protection programmes.  Dominica Digital payments to beneficiaries should be explored as they enhance convenience and contribute to financial inclusion and transparency. A dedicated hotline or digital platform is recommended to allow beneficiaries to submit complaints and feedback easily and enhance the Complaints and Feedback Mechanism.  Virgin Islands (UK)  System development requires a simple and iterative approach. For example,  the use of simpler, off-the-shelf tools such as Kobo for intake and Excel for storage was fundamental to setting the foundation for improving systems in the Virgin Islands.   A comprehensive assessment to review processes and capacities within social protection systems are necessary prerequisites for the digitalization process. Only after establishing this foundational knowledge and building a common roadmap to realize the envisioned change can tools and technologies, and subsequent ‚Äòdigitization‚Äô efforts occur. This proposed approach ensures that digital enhancements are built upon solid, well-understood processes and protocols.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Equality, Well-Being and Leaving No One Behind
Outcome: People in the Caribbean equitably access and utilize universal, quality and shock-responsive, social protection, education, health, and care services
Output: 1.4.18 BDS National governments and regional institutions in the Caribbean have strengthened capacity to prepare for, adapt and respond to shocks and climate change
Sub-Output: 2.4.18 BDS Vulnerable populations benefit from strengthened social protection systems that reduce poverty, boost resilience and provide assistance to shock affected people in order to protect their access to food and livelihood
Description: WFP seeks to ensure that regional and national institutions can meet the immediate essential needs of vulnerable men, women, boys and girls in times of crisis. This will be achieved through strengthening institutional capacity to respond to shocks in areas of WFP‚Äôs comparative advantage, including end-to-end supply chain management, food systems, social protection, vulnerability analysis and mapping, digitalization and digital solutions and innovative disaster risk financing.
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: European Union; The Joint SDG Fund; United States Agency for International Development Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance; World Food Programme Multi-donor
Implementation partners: Barbados Ministry of People Empowerment and Elder Affairs; British Virgin Island Ministry Of Health And Social Development; Saint Lucia Ministry of Equity, Social Justice, and People's Empowerment; Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Ministry of National Mobilization, Social Development, Family, Gender Affairs, Youth, Housing and Informal Human Settlement
SDG Targets: 17.9 Enhance international support for implementing effective and targeted capacity-building in developing countries to support national plans to implement all the sustainable development goals, including through North-South, South-South and triangular cooperation.
Geography: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines; Saint Kitts and Nevis; Dominica; Antigua and Barbuda; Virgin Islands, British; Barbados; Grenada; Saint Lucia; Anguilla (United Kingdom)
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis; Policy Advice and Thought Leadership; Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2022 Narrative: WFP‚Äôs work on capacity strengthening provides support to regional and national institutions to strengthen social protection systems to respond to shock ensuring that the immediate essential needs of the vulnerable can be met in times of crisis. WFP carries out activities to enhance social protection systems at the national level to increase their capacity to reduce poverty and vulnerability and provide assistance to shock-affected people. WFP Caribbean‚Äôs work on capacity strengthening includes regional learning, knowledge exchanges and training efforts and in 2022, WFP administered shock-responsive social protection trainings for government partners in Barbados, Saint Lucia and Dominica , with the aim of enhancing participant's understanding of social protection, disaster risk management, and how preparation, response and mitigation of impacts from shocks are linked. Trainings on data management and digitization were also provided in the countries:-         In Barbados, a total of 19 people were trained (18 females and 1 male) under shock-responsive social protection and on December 19 persons were trained on the use of a digital data collection tool for the tracking of a countrywide food hamper distribution. WFP continued supporting the Government of Barbados to strengthen digital payment reconciliation processes, digital data collection and post-distribution monitoring by carrying out trainings for Ministry of People Empowerment and Elder Affairs (MPEA) staff. WFP donated 115 tablets to the MPEA to further assist with these efforts. -         In Dominica, WFP provided technical assistance piloting digital data collection registration for the public assistance programme. A training was also conducted on shock responsive social protection and a workshop on the standard operating procedures (SOPs) for shock-responsive social protection. A total of 18 and 22 individuals participated in the training sessions respectively. -         In the Virgin Islands (UK) WFP supported the implementation of the House of Assembly (HOA) Transitional Grant. This transition moved social grants previously under the House of Assembly to the Social Development Department (SDD), in a reform to increase accountability, efficiency, and inclusion. WFP provided technical support to the SDD to review the process of the delivery chain of Public Assistance, and to digitalize it (digital data collection, analysis of data to establish eligibility and grants amount, and delivery and monitoring of assistance delivery). Substantial progress was made in strengthening social protection information management systems, using a twin-track approach to meeting immediate information management needs with the House of Assembly transition of social grants previously under the HOA to the Social Development Department, while setting the base for a more comprehensive system. A mission was undertaken by WFP‚Äôs Senior Information Management Systems Advisor and technical support provided to the government to develop an interim digital system (the development, piloting, refinement and implementation of digital data collection forms, the development of the database, Training of the implementation team with the new methodology). These elements are enabling efficient and accountable information management processes within the accelerated timeline for implementation of the HOA Transitional Grant. Digital data collection processes enable disaggregation by sex and other characteristics, strengthening opportunities for gender-response analysis.   -          In Saint Lucia, a vulnerability index was developed with the government and piloted in 2022. The index aims to inform response planning for shock-responsive social protection and overall social protection policy and system strengthening and is useful in helping the government to identify vulnerable people before a disaster strikes and is designed to enable social assistance to support households most vulnerable and impacted by weather-related hazards and other shocks, by informing response planning, assistance targeting and delivery, the development of operational guidance and overall systems strengthening. Trainings were also conducted in various areas of social protection, with the objective of strengthening existing government systems. For example, a data Visualization training was provided to staff of the Ministries of Equity, Health, Education, and the Central Statistical Office , focusing on principles of data collection, data cleaning and preparation and introduction to Power BI. A total of 13 officers were trained in to better analyze and visualize raw data and to present it in easily understandable graphical presentations.  The training was part of the Ministry of Equity‚Äôs efforts to strengthen competencies and capacity in data management techniques. Twenty-nine government officials received online training in shock-responsive social protection to enhance capacities to strengthen the social protection system through preparedness measure and build technical competencies in designing and implementing shock-responsive social protection programmes at the individual, household, and community levels. In Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, WFP has provided technical support and guidance to the government in the targeting, verification, and consolidation of the beneficiary list for WFP cash assistance and the World Bank's 6-month cash program. WFP has engaged with the Ministry of National Mobilization in discussions to identify gaps in previous programs, resulting in a technical agreement to strengthen the system to reduce poverty and vulnerability, increase resilience, and provide assistance to those affected by the shock that will be signed in 2023. Through the Joint Programme, signed in April 2022, WFP and FAO will draw on the power of data, information systems and sectoral linkages to mitigate the impacts of climate change and related shocks at the household, community and national levels, promote and protect food security, livelihoods and strengthen resilience in a gender-responsive manner.  Lessons Learned:¬∑  The vulnerability index in Saint Lucia has the potential to strengthen inter-institutional collaboration and coordination and offers a lot of potential for making social assistance transfers or other development interventions more efficient, effective, and impactful. There is the possibility to explore the application of the vulnerability index in the context of socio-economic shocks beyond natural hazards and link it with livelihood analysis. Strengthening partnerships with ministries by establishing data linkages and sharing arrangements, especially for social assistance registries, household surveys and spatial information, and consider centralizing datasets where possible is key.
2023 Narrative: Under strategic outcome 1 of its 2022-2026 Multi-Country Strategic Plan, WFP provides capacity strengthening support to national governments and institutions to strengthen disaster management and social protection systems to ensure that the immediate essential needs of the vulnerable can be met in times of crisis. WFP Caribbean‚Äôs work on social protection capacity strengthening includes regional learning, knowledge exchanges and training efforts and in 2023, WFP continued to administer trainings in different areas of social protection with the aim of improving the shock responsiveness of national systems. Trainings were conducted in following countries:  In support of national efforts to strengthen social protection, including in response to shocks, WFP in collaboration with UNICEF, conducted training in shock responsive social protection in Anguilla.  A total of 24 participants (18 females and 6 males) were trained at the 3.5-day event from organizations including the Ministry of Social Development (Department of Social Development; Gender Affairs Unit); Department of Labour; Anguilla Social Security Board; Department of Disaster Management; Anguilla Fire  Rescue; Ministry of Finance; Department of Information Technology and E-Government Services (DITES); Health Authority of Anguilla (HAA); Anguilla Red Cross. At the request of the Government of Saint Kitts and Nevis, WFP and UNCEF jointly facilitated a training in shock responsive social protection, which brought together.  28 individuals (25 females and 3 males) from the Ministry of Social Development and Gender Affairs; the Nevis Island Administration (NIA); the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) and the Nevis Disaster Management Department (NDMD).. To complement ongoing support to the Government of the Virgin Islands (UK) to improve national social protection systems, WFP trained 33 (29 females and 4 males) social protection and disaster management professionals.. The workshop focused on how the current system could be more responsive and helped to facilitate coordination among social protection, disaster management and other entities.  In order to expand the usage of a digital form, jointly developed by MPEA and the Government of Barbados, WFP was invited to  train an additional 34 (27 females and 7 males) social workers at the Ministry of People Empowerment and Elder Affairs (MPEA) on how to use the KoboCollect app to conduct the MPEA Emergency Relief/Socio-Economic Assessment. The digital form was jointly developed by WFP and the MPEA in 2022. In March, WFP also improved the ministry‚Äôs ability to conducted post distribution monitoring by training 2 MPEA staff. To meet data interpretation, data analysis and to improve understanding of statistics concepts in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, WFP partnered with the Ministry of National Mobilisation to provide Data Essentials Training to 21 (15 males and 6 females) staff.  Further, as part of the Joint SDG Fund project with FAO, WFP also helped to inprove knowledge and skills in shock responsive social protection to 26 individuals, including 20 females and 6 males government staff from the Ministry of National Mobilisation (et al), National Emergency Management Organization, Ministry of Health, Wellness and the Environment and the Ministry of Education and National Reconciliation participated in the training.  In May , as part of an SDG Joint programme, WFP, UNICEF and ILO brought permanent secretaries and other technical persons from social protection ministries to discuss strategies, best practices, challenges and solutions for developing national information management sessions.  WFP places significant emphasis on regional partnerships in alignment with Caribbean countries' commitment to regional integration and collaboration. As such, country's financial requirements and funding availability reflect also regional contributions implemented by WFP through its partnerships with regional institutions including CDEMA, CARICOM and/or OECS, among others.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Resilience to Climate Change and Sustainable Natural Resource Management
Outcome: Caribbean people, communities, and institutions enhance their adaptive capacity for inclusive, gender responsive DRM and climate change adaptation and mitigation
Output: 1.5.21 BDS Crisis-affected populations in the Caribbean are able to meet their food, nutrition and other essential needs during and in the aftermath of shocks;
Sub-Output: 2.5.21 BDS Affected populations receive cash-based transfers or in-kind food assistance in order to meet essential needs, protect livelihoods and preserve their nutrition status.
Description: WFP will assist shock-affected populations with cash-based transfers or food in-kind in response to events necessitating international assistance. This outcome focuses on meeting food, nutrition and other essential needs of shock-affected people
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: United Nations World Food Programme
Implementation partners: Barbados Ministry of People Empowerment and Elder Affairs; Saint Lucia Ministry of Equity, Social Justice, and People's Empowerment; Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Ministry of National Mobilization, Social Development, Family, Gender Affairs, Youth, Housing and Informal Human Settlement
SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.
Geography: Saint Lucia; Saint Vincent and the Grenadines; Barbados; Virgin Islands, British; Dominica
QCPR function: Direct Support/ Service Delivery; Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Other (including coordination)
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: In an emergency, WFP supports national emergency response efforts to assist affected persons.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: In an emergency, WFP supports national emergency response efforts to assist affected persons.
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
Sustaining peace marker narrative: In an emergency, WFP supports national emergency response efforts to assist affected persons.
2022 Narrative: WFP assisted shock-affected populations through the provision of cash assistance. Assistance is provided through existing government‚Äôs social protection systems targeting those most in need including people with disabilities, single female- headed households, the elderly and other economically and socially marginalized groups. In response to the socio-economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, in 2022 WFP provided cash assistance valued at US$ 50,260 to 593 individuals (of which 346 were women) as part of the national response to COVID-19 in Barbados . 12,084 food hampers were also distributed to vulnerable people (6,632 women) impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic and the rising cost of living in Barbados in December 2022. The beneficiaries were identified and verified using a rapid assessment form which was developed by the MPEA.In Saint Lucia, WFP supported cash-based transfer assistance to a total of 654 beneficiaries (310 males, 341 females) affected by Hurricane Elsa to support the recovery of households affected. The cash transfers were part of the broader pilot on shock-responsive social protection which also tested the household vulnerability index as well a digital payment mechanism. The cash transfers complemented the support provided for the temporary expansion of the Public Assistance Programme as part of the Government‚Äôs broader pandemic response strategy.In St. Vincent and the Grenadines, WFP continued to support people affected by the volcano eruption in 2021 providing cash, vouchers and school feeding. In 2022, cash assistance was provided to individuals, supporting 18,044 people. Around 1,308 people who were already facing financial challenges due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic received value vouchers redeemable at a local supermarket chain, which helped them in meeting their essential needs. Additionally, WFP also worked with the Ministry of Education and National Reconciliation to financially support a school meals programme assisting 669 students identified as eligible through the government school feeding platform.WFP supported the expansion of the Public Assistance Programme also in Dominica, increasing the value of transfers made to existing beneficiaries and enabling the programme to identify and temporarily incorporate new households, for which digital registration was introduced. In total, 5,235 people received cash assistance to mitigate the socioeconomic impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic.  Lessons Learned:¬∑      More efforts should be put into fostering greater linkages between the National Emergency Management Organization and other government entities in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines to boost more creative and efficient programmatic solutions in areas like cash-based transfers and data sharing between government agencies.-     Strengthening data management tools is essential to ensure efficient and effective assistance.¬∑       When designing activities,  technological literacy needs to be considered, especially amongst the elderly as some elderly might face difficulties in navigating digital payment platforms.
2023 Narrative: In response to events that necessitates assistance, WFP provides support to shock-affected populations through cash-based transfers or food in-kind assistance to ensure that food, nutrition, and other essential needs of the vulnerable are met in times of crisis.  In January 2023, WFP continued to provide food assistance in Barbados in partnership with the Ministry of People Empowerment and Elder Affairs (MPEA) to households at risk of food insecurity due to the impact of COVID-19 and the rising cost of living.  A total of 10,128 individuals (5,804 females and 4,324 males) received food kits in January. The beneficiaries were identified and verified using a rapid assessment form which was developed by the (MPEA). The distribution of food kits was implemented through cross-agency collaboration among the MPEA, the Barbados Defense Force, the Department of Emergency Management and the Barbados Association of Professional Social Workers (BAPSW), with cross-cutting technical support from WFP. The distribution was monitored and tracked through a digital data collection software used by the field teams in the communities.  Additionally, WFP and the government of Dominica partnered to provide financial assistance to impacted households as part of a shock responsive social protection approach to mitigate the socio-economic impacts caused by a trough system that affected the country in 2022.  A total of 1,333 (651 females and 682 males) people received assistance under the cash transfer programme which was instrumental in helping beneficiaries cushion the impacts on disruptions to their livelihood activities and meeting their food and other essential needs. 637 households in 5 communities were identified by the Ministry of Health, Wellness and Social Services to receive the cash assistance depending on the family size, households with a total of 1-2 members received XCD 400 or XCD 750 for 3 or more members.  Lessons learned:  Dominica  Strengthening data management tools is essential to ensure efficient and effective assistance.   A comprehensive re-evaluation of cash assistance bands is crucial to ensure that they align with the evolving cost of basic needs. In-depth assessment of living expenses, considering factors like inflation and regional variations is recommended. Major government changes like elections can impact and delay responses through government social protection systems especially if there is a reshuffling of ministries, as responsibilities and counterparts can change. WFP had been working closely with civil servants and technical persons at different levels. Engagement at the more technical, implementation level is particularly critical as these positions have the institutional knowledge amid transitions. Institutionalization of shock-response processes through documentation and SOPs is important so that knowledge stays even if personnel in government change.

Plan name: United Nations Development Assistance Framework
Strategic priority: Soberan√≠a y Seguridad Alimentaria y Nutricional
Outcome: Efecto Directo 3.1.
Output: 3.1.1 Programas o pol√≠ticas orientadas a incrementar la producci√≥n local de alimentos fortalecidas para mejorar la resiliencia de las comunidades rurales vulnerables a seguridad alimentaria y al cambio clim√°tico, considerando el enfoque de g√©nero
Sub-Output: 3.1.1.1. Global Network Against Food Crises Partnership Programme - Country Investment Venezuela
Description: GCP /VEN/017/EC
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: European Commission Directorate-General for International Cooperation and Development
Implementation partners: Venezuela Ministerio del Poder Popular para la Planificaci√≥n
SDG Targets: 1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.,2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Resilience to Climate Change and Sustainable Natural Resource Management
Outcome: Caribbean countries manage natural resources and ecosystems to strengthen their resilience and enhance the resilience and prosperity of the people and communities that depend on them.
Output: MSDCF 6.1: Environmental management institutions strengthened for sustainable natural resource management
Sub-Output: BAH Integrated Landscape Management for land degradation, food security and climate resilience in the Bahamas
Description: Integrated Landscape Management for Addressing Land Degradation, Food Security and Climate Resilience Challenges in The Bahamas (GEF-7 #10694). A national, technical assistance project to enhance climate resilient food production across productive agricultural landscapes through sound Integrated Landscape Management and Land Degradation Neutrality approaches in The Bahamas.  The project considers long-term solutions to address problems of land degradation and increase implementation of sustainable land management (SLM) practices through an integrated landscape management planning approach, with restorative measures that reduce the drivers of land degradation and mitigation of loss of productivity within agricultural and natural ecosystems, while enhancing resilience to climate change.
Agencies: United Nations Environment Programme
Contributing partners: The Global Environment Facility
Implementation partners: Bahamas Ministry of Agriculture and Marine Resources; Bahamas Ministry of Environment and Housing
SDG Targets: 15.1 By 2020, ensure the conservation, restoration and sustainable use of terrestrial and inland freshwater ecosystems and their services, in particular forests, wetlands, mountains and drylands, in line with obligations under international agreements.,15.3 By 2030, combat desertification, restore degraded land and soil, including land affected by desertification, drought and floods, and strive to achieve a land degradation-neutral world.
QCPR function: Normative Support; Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
Focal users: Lourdes Guerrero; Priyanka Mais; Deirdre Shurland
2022 Narrative: The BAH SLM Project has 4 Components: 1) Strengthening the enabling environment for achievement of land degradation neutrality through improved policy and governance; 2) Demonstration of sustainable land management, regenerative climate-smart agriculture production systems, practices and technologies; 3) Incentivizing uptake and replication of SLM and climate resilient agriculture; and 4) Enhancing monitoring and knowledge management systems for LDN assessment and agricultural production system resilience assessment and tracking related GEB Indicators. The Inception Workshop opening project activities with national and regional stakeholders was launched 24th November 2022.
2024 Narrative: In spite of contract signing delays with the collaborating partner institutions, 7 of 8 collaborating institutions are onboard executing deliverables: work under Components 1 and 2 are most advanced, while Components 3 and 4 are substantially dependent on outputs from Components #1 and 2. Progress: Component #1: led by the Partnership Initiative for Sustainable Land Management (PISLM) - has completed with stakeholders the Land Assessment Report and updated the 2006 National Action Program (NAP) aligned to UNCCD Strategy, with both now tabled in the Parliament and awaiting Cabinet Review as the official national SLM policy. Component #2: Stakeholder consultations on 7 Islands are completed on the SLM demonstration sites; Component #3: The Bahamas Development Bank is the lead IP; Component #4: The University of the Bahamas is the lead for the establishment of a National Environmental-Agricultural Production Information System (NEAPIS).

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Equality, Well-Being and Leaving No One Behind
Outcome: People in the Caribbean equitably access and utilize universal, quality and shock-responsive, social protection, education, health, and care services
Output: BZE 4.1 By 2024, national institutional capacity enhanced to assess, analyse, predict, prevent, and respond to social vulnerability and shocks in both non-emergency and emergency settings
Sub-Output: BZE 4.1.1: Vulnerable populations in Belize benefit from strengthened social protection systems that reduce poverty and vulnerability,  boost resilience and provide assistance to shock-affected people in order to protect their access to food and livelihoods
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: European Union; The Joint SDG Fund; United States Agency for International Development Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance; World Food Programme Multi-donor
Implementation partners: Belize Ministry of Human Development, Families, and Indigeneos Peoples' Affairs
SDG Targets: 17.9 Enhance international support for implementing effective and targeted capacity-building in developing countries to support national plans to implement all the sustainable development goals, including through North-South, South-South and triangular cooperation.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2022 Narrative: Outcome 4: People in the Caribbean equitably access and utilize universal, quality and shock-responsive, social protection, education, health, and care services.WFP Highlights from 2022	Strengthened government capacity to respond to shock by improving the operational plan for the Relief and Supplies Management Committee of the National Emergency Management Organization which was utilized during the Hurricane Lisa response.  	 Social protection and disaster management systems were strengthened to provide assistance in times of crisis through the digitalization of data collection processes, data visualization, and the use of digital payments.Key Focus Areas for 2023Strengthen analytical processes/capacities informed by a consultative process with key stakeholders, to enable more effective response to shocks and disasters.Support the Ministry of Human Development with model for a scalable and shock-responsive social protection program that can mobilize assistance to vulnerable populations to increase their resilience to shocks.Main results:WFP‚Äôs work on capacity strengthening provides support to regional and national institutions to strengthen social protection systems to respond to shock ensuring that the immediate essential needs of the vulnerable can be met in times of crisis. In 2022, WFP carried out activities to enhance social protection systems at the national level to increase the internal technical/operational capacity of the Government to plan and implement shock-responsive social protection programmes and systems in Belize to respond to shocks through the following: -         In partnership with the Ministry of Human Development, Families, and Indigenous Affairs (MHDFIPA), WFP provided technical and advisory support to enhance the operational plan for the Relief and Supplies Management Committee (RSMC) of the National Emergency Management Organization (NEMO) to include various modalities of assistance (including cash), targeting criteria, instrument for data collection, monitoring, determination of the amount assistance for relief to support food and other essential needs and grievance redress. The RSMC‚Äôs updated operational plan was endorsed by NEMO prior to Hurricane Lisa in November and was tested during the hurricane response in 2022. -         WFP Caribbean‚Äôs work on capacity strengthening also included regional learning, knowledge exchanges and training efforts and in 2022, WFP administered a face-to face shock-responsive social protection training in Belize, with the aim of enhancing participants understanding of social protection, disaster risk management, and how preparation, response and mitigation of impacts from shocks are linked. A total of 26 participants were trained from the Belize National Emergency Management Organization and the Ministry of Human Development. In October 2022, focus group discussions were facilitated by WFP with specific vulnerable groups in Belize, namely, Indigenous communities (Maya and Garifuna), farmers (in Toledo and Stann Creek Districts), and representatives of people with disabilities. Around 40 individuals participated in the focus group discussions which aimed to gather impacts of the ongoing food and energy crises to livelihoods, spending on food and other essential needs, and overall well-being of these specific vulnerable groups that were not captured in the Food Security and Livelihoods Round Survey administered by WFP and CARICOM in August 2022. Highlights of the focus group discussions will be documented in the Special Focus of the Belize Country Report, which is expected to be finalized in December 2022. -         Additionally, WFP provided advisory and technical support in building a long-term partnership between the Government, the Ministry of Human Development, Families and Indigenous Peoples' Affairs (MHDFIPA) and a local financial service provider to establish a digital payment system within the Government which can be immediately mobilized in response to future shocks/crises. While previous digital payment solutions have been used in the English-speaking Caribbean the use of digital payments provides greater options for utilizing assistance and can help promote financial inclusion and economic empowerment of the most vulnerable and give people payment options for a more tailored and improved payment experience.Lessons learned:-  Coordination systems within the Government‚Äôs structure could be further improved. As such, UN agencies should play a more significant role in working collaboratively to improve coordination, minimize duplications and maximize and sustain investments. - Adequacy of assistance to families affected by shocks and emergencies needs to be assessed periodically to examine how effectively the essential needs of those affected are being met.- Simulation exercises should be done annually prior to the start of foreseen perennial shocks (such as hurricanes, excessive flooding during the rainy season) to test if plans, systems, and resources are adequate to respond to foreseen needs.
2023 Narrative: Main results:WFP‚Äôs work on capacity strengthening provides support to regional and national institutions to strengthen social protection systems to respond to shocks ensuring that the immediate essential needs of the vulnerable can be met in times of disasters and crisis. In 2023, WFP carried out activities to enhance social protection systems at the national level to increase the internal technical/operational capacity of the Government to plan and implement shock-responsive social protection programmes and systems in Belize through the following: ¬∑      Parallel to providing cash assistance under the Hurricane Lisa cash assistance Programmes, WFP partnered with the government to strengthen verification, monitoring, and reporting mechanisms for cash assistance through the use of digital tools to improve social assistance delivery. Eleven staff members (4 females and 7 males) from the Ministry of Human Development, Family and Indigenous People Affairs (MHDFIPA) and the Ministry of Agriculture, Food Security and Enterprise (MAFSE) benefitted from trainings to design digital tools that capture vulnerability data to facilitate verification of potential beneficiaries under the national social protection systems. Support through training was also provided for post-distribution monitoring for the same staff of MHDFIPA and MAFSE, enabling the government to cascade the training to 20 local enumerators (11 females and 9 males). This support was aimed at further strengthening the Government's existing capacities in shock response to ensure the needs of the vulnerable can be met in a timely and effective manner.  ¬∑      WFP has a strong commitment to documenting the journey of building resilience through its approach to capacity strengthening and innovation. This component is important for opportunities for knowledge exchange, to influence national and regional policies and, more importantly, to continue to find solutions for increased resilience to compound shocks. In 2022 with the support of WFP the MHDFIPA updated its National Relief  Supplies Management Plan (RSMP) to guide the delivery of its mandate to ensure that adequate food, psychosocial services, and other relief assistance are available to affected populations in times of disasters. The RSMP was put to the test in 2022 with the events of excessive flooding and hurricane. In May 2023, WFP facilitated a Lessons Learned workshop on the 2022 Relief and Supplies Management Plan (RSMP) of the National Emergency Management Office (NEMO) to assist the MHDFIPA to strengthen the shock-responsiveness of the RSMP by consolidating lessons and recommendations from key actors. Approximately 33 staff from MHDFIPA and NEMO Secretariat participated in the workshop. WFP and the MHDFIPA jointly produced a Lessons Learned Workshop Report which served as an internal document of the RSMC of Belize‚Äôs NEMO. The discussions and recommendations in the report represent solely the views of the Government participants and will be considered in updating the RSMP. ¬∑      WFP assisted the government to update the shock-responsive social protection Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) to define processes and actions for preparedness and details on registration, targeting and delivery mechanisms for disaster response based on lessons learned from the Hurricane Lisa response. ¬∑      Support to monitoring systems, payments systems, standard operational procedures, digital tools, design of cash-based transfers (targeting, transfer values, etc), and shock-responsiveness of all these measures form part of WFP‚Äôs overall support to developing Belize‚Äôs social protection system and strategy. Since 2022, WFP together with other UN agencies have been continuously consulting with local stakeholders to assist the Government in formulating its National Social Protection Framework, which culminated in a Social Protection Summit in October 2023. A draft of the SP Framework is expected by mid-2024.   Lessons learned: (1)   Government ownership of systems and processes is important to a successful program implementation and in demonstrating good practices for wider Government adoption.  (2)   Small and carefully designed pilot programs allow the Government to try innovative approaches within a more controlled low-risk environment. WFP should more proactively explore financing support for these types of pilots that can have significant demonstration effects.  (3)   Documentation of experiences through PDMs of 2 pilot programs (HLAP with MHDFIPA and HL-RAP with MAFSE) on the use of cash for relief assistance and digital solutions as a delivery mechanism provided sufficient evidence for NEMO to formally adopt these approaches as part of their Relief and Supplies Management Plan (RSMP) for 2023 onwards.

2022 Narrative: FAO supported to The Statistics Bureau of Guyana with the implementation of the FIES survey module into a National Household survey. This was an important step in order to have objective data, comparable with other countries increasing the country capacities to measure and monitor the SDG Targets including the Prevalence of Food Insecurity. The Country Office is committed to provide support with the data analysis and strengthen the national capacity for the implementation.With FAOs assistance a Strategic Plan for Agricultural and Rural Statistics (SPARS) was developed. The SPARS in Guyana entails a five-year implementation plan by the Ministry of Agriculture (MoA), and incorporates all agricultural agencies' activities linked to the generation and production of agricultural data. These data help policymakers and other stakeholders make evidence-based decisions and track the success of the agricultural sector.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Equality, Well-Being and Leaving No One Behind
Outcome: People in the Caribbean equitably access and utilize universal, quality and shock-responsive, social protection, education, health, and care services
Output: GUY Output 4.3 Support provided to broaden coverage and depth of social protection and social care services in both emergency and non-emergency situations/contexts
Sub-Output: GUY SubOutput 4.3.1: 'Social protection system strengthening' - Vulnerable populations in the Caribbean benefit from strengthened social protection systems that reduce poverty and vulnerability,  boost resilience and provide assistance to shock-affected people in order to protect their access to food and livelihoods
Description: WFP seeks to ensure that regional and national institutions can meet the immediate essential needs of vulnerable men, women, boys and girls in times of crisis. This will be achieved through strengthening institutional capacity to respond to shocks in areas of WFP‚Äôs comparative advantage, including end-to-end supply chain management, food systems, social protection, vulnerability analysis and mapping, digitalization and digital solutions and innovative disaster risk financing.
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: European Union; Government of Canada; United Kingdom Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office; United Nations World Food Programme; United States Agency for International Development; World Food Programme Multi-donor
Implementation partners: Guyana Ministry of Human Service and Social Security
SDG Targets: 17.9 Enhance international support for implementing effective and targeted capacity-building in developing countries to support national plans to implement all the sustainable development goals, including through North-South, South-South and triangular cooperation.
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis; Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing; Policy Advice and Thought Leadership; Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2022 Narrative: WFP‚Äôs support to the Government of Guyana continued in 2022 to strengthen the implementation of the WIIN programme, particularly around beneficiary data and information management and monitoring of the cash distribution in early 2022. Guyana also benefitted from the sharing of knowledge on the use of social protection to meet the needs of vulnerable, poor people, and for affected populations in times of crisis. In partnership with the Ministry of Human Services and Social Security (MHSSS), WFP bolstered the Innovation and Investment Network programme by targeting the most vulnerable and poor households, particularly women and girls with cash assistance. Recipients of the cash grant highlighted that it helped them to improve food consumption, reduce stress and increased feelings of empowerment and facilitated investments in livelihoods.                   In August 2022, WFP administered one face-to-face shock-responsive social protection training for government counterparts in Guyana, with the aim of enhancing participants understanding of shock-responsive social protection, disaster risk management, and how preparation, response and mitigation of impacts from shocks are linked. A total of 20 people were trained of which 12 were women.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        WFP carried out activities to support national efforts in the delivery of social protection programmes that target the most vulnerable. Through partnership with the Ministry of Human Services and Social Security to deliver cash-based social assistance, WFP delivered capacity-strengthening trainings to 10 people (of which 8 were women) through knowledge transfer on best practices, procedures and results orientation in distribution of cash assistance. WFP also provided advisory services on beneficiary data and information management for social protection programmes.
2023 Narrative: In 2023 WFP partnered with the Government of Guyana to strengthen national social protection systems to better meet the needs of impacted people when a shock occurs. Parallel to providing cash assistance under the government‚Äôs Women Innovation Investment and Networking (WIIN) programme, WFP provided technical support to the government in beneficiary targeting processes to improve effectiveness of the programme and service delivery by improving skills of 2 Ministry staff in beneficiary information management, cash transfers distribution planning, and payment reconciliation.  WFP has a strong commitment to documenting the journey of building resilience through its approach to capacity strengthening and innovation. This component is important for opportunities for knowledge exchange, to influence national and regional policies and, more importantly, to continue to find solutions for increased resilience to compound shocks. In May 2023, a lessons-learned workshop was held on previous cash transfers distributed through the WIIN programme under the now-concluded Development Emergency Modality Joint Sustainable Development Goal Fund. 10 participants (5 males and 5 females) from the Ministry of Human Services and Social Security, Deeds and Commercial Registry Authority and the Office of the Auditor General were in attendance and the workshop created opportunities for the government to identify lessons and good practices regarding cash transfers that can be used to inform response to future shocks.To further solidify the existing partnership and to ensure the direct needs of the vulnerable are met against the current environment and trends, a visioning workshop was held between WFP and MHSSS to outline the way forward on partnering for technical assistance and capacity strengthening. Discussions will guide efforts in 2024 as WFP and the government continue to work together to meet the needs of the vulnerable and ensure no one is left behind.

Sub-Output: Strengthening food systems in order to increase access to affordable and nutritious food for food insecure populations
Description: 2023- Provide technical support to the development and operationalizing of National Food Plan as a follow-up to the commitment on 25 by 25 commitment; Support with food security and livelihoods data through the implementation of surveys
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: United Nations World Food Programme; World Food Programme Multi-donor
Implementation partners: Trinidad and Tobago Office of the Prime Minister
SDG Targets: 17.9 Enhance international support for implementing effective and targeted capacity-building in developing countries to support national plans to implement all the sustainable development goals, including through North-South, South-South and triangular cooperation.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2022 Narrative: 1.Caribbean food security and livelihoods surveys completed in February and August 2022, which allow the Government to get a snapshot of the situation in the country.
2023 Narrative: In 2023, WFP partnered with the government of Trinidad and Tobago to strengthen the resilience of food systems to meet the nutritional needs of the vulnerable. In partnership with the Office of the Prime Minister (Gender and Child Affairs), WFP provided technical guidance for the composition of a food basket based on the WFP NutVal tool for Gender based violence victims. The food basket is tailored to local preferences, demographic profile, activity levels, climatic conditions and local coping capacity ensuring the government can effectively meet the nutritional requirements of targeted populations under social programmes providing food assistance.  Additionally, WFP collaborated with the National School Dietary Services Limited to improve efficiency and resource management in designing school menus for nutrition programmes in Trinidad and Tobago. During the year WFP provided trainings to three nutritionists (all females) based at the National School Meals Dietary on the AI-driven School Menu Planning (SMP) tool which is a software that allows users to save time and resources in designing school menus that are tailored to local context and nutritional needs. Following the training, WFP made this innovative tool available to the Government of Trinidad and Tobago. Partnering with the Ministry of Youth Development and National Service (MYDNS), WFP engaged in the promotion of activities aimed at attracting youth in agriculture. Given that the MYDNS launched a number of Youth in Agriculture programmes, WFP closely interacted with the coordinators of these programmes and supported Youth Caravan campaigns. Within the framework on National Disaster Prevention and Preparedness month that is marked in May in Trinidad and Tobago, WFP together with the Institute of Inter-American Cooperation in Agriculture (IICA) conducted a workshop for farmers on disaster preparedness. Almost 40 farmers received training on the best practices and tools that could help in saving crops from the losses caused by disasters. WFP also joined IICA in initiating the development partner forum on food security and agriculture during the year. The first meeting brought together participants from the Ministry of Agriculture, private sector, academia, international and regional organisations and looked at the options for Trinidad and Tobago in the context of 25 by 25 initiative, i.e. reducing food imports by 25 percent by the year 2025. As a result, currently the work is ongoing on the draft of food production plan put together by the Ministry of Agriculture.Upon the invitation from the Ministry of Health, WFP became a member of the Project Steering Committee on the Food Consumption and Nutrition Survey. WFP presented its methodology in conducting food security assessments and advised government officials on the most appropriate indicators and tools that could be used in Trinidad and Tobago. Based on this engagement, the Ministry of Health is considering incorporating WFP-suggested methodology in the Food Consumption Survey that is planned for 2024.In May 2023, WFP administered the sixth round of the food security and livelihoods survey on behalf of CARICOM. The survey results revealed that 3.7 million out of 7.1 million people, or 52 percent of the population of the English-speaking Caribbean, remain food insecure. While this is a 10 percent decrease when compared to an August 2022 survey, the results highlighted growing financial hardship and challenges due to the rising cost of living in the aftermath of the pandemic. The surveys continue to play a critical role in informing analysis and decision-making for governments and development partners in the region and have significantly contributed to the current prioritization of the food security agenda. In August 2023, WFP published a country-specific Food Security and Livelihood Survey summary for Trinidad and Tobago allowing the government to get a snapshot of the situation in the country. According to the report, people continue to experience challenges to their livelihoods due to the current cost of living crisis. Most respondents to the survey reported significant price increases in food, housing, gas, health and fuels and food consumption patterns show challenges with food security in the country. https://www.wfp.org/publications/caribbean-food-security-livelihoods-survey-may-2023

SDG Targets: 2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,5.5 Ensure women's full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life,5.a Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.,8.5 By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.,9.3 Increase the access of small-scale industrial and other enterprises, in particular in developing countries, to financial services, including affordable credit, and their integration into value chains and markets.

QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis; Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2022 Narrative: "1. The JP looked at production and productivity aspects and inclusivity -Analyses were completed on soil and pineapple types with a view to introducing innovative and sustainable production technologies. Two trial farms were set up in the Marowjine and Matta regions. More than 130 (including 35% women) farmers attended training sessions on establishing permanent systems that require less land and reduce pressure on the primary and secondary forests.2. The JP strengthened collaboration within the value chain and continued to form new partnerships, particularly with reference to leveraging of funds. New partnerships are being discussed with the local Trustbank Amanah (TBA) to provide loans to farmers, and with the Islamic Development Bank (IsDB) to provide a top-up for the collateral guarantees, 3. build the capacity of the TBA, and support organic certification. Furthermore, the JP also established collaboration with Wageningen University (WUR), in the Netherlands, to provide expert advice on the set-up and management of cooperatives in Suriname and on the establishment of a packed house; as well as with the CARIPI project to leverage its actions on intellectual property protection and brand creation.4. Digital traceability platforms for small pineapple producers developed to allow users to access knowledge on growing technologies, and harvest management practices to reduce loss ensuring better quality and quantity, in addition to providing information on markets and requirements. "
2023 Narrative: The ASTA project has directly addressed SDG 2, SDG 5, and SDG 8.all. To do so, the project developed and submitted its official proposal to the Suriname Government to establish the legal entity which will be responsible for providing key services to organic producers, as well as ensuring the sustainability of the activities currently carried out by ASTA, the Horticulture Innovation Hub. This accelerates transitions towards SDGs 1 (No Poverty), 2 (Zero Hunger) and 8 (Decent Work and Economic Growth).¬∑ In terms of gender equality (SDG 5) the project provided targeted year-round trainings in good agricultural practices and organic production empowering farmers. The ASTA project is in finalization stage with IsDB about receiving $300.000 to support the ASTA activities in Suriname. This funding will support the project to increase the collateral support facility that provides access to collateral to farmers and project beneficiaries. Meanwhile, the team continues its resource mobilization efforts for additional funding from various potential donors, e.g., Caribbean Development Bank and establishing synergies with existing financial mechanisms and facilities in Suriname, including UN projects, NOB, IDB, LVV NOFA fund, the World Bank SURGE program.¬∑ Under the ASTA project over 233 people were trained in 2023, from which 114 females. In total 17 training courses were conducted under the ASTA project.¬∑ The project supported pineapple farmers improve their farming methods. Training enabled farmers to increase their knowledge on soil management and fertilizers and organic materials usage for improved crops. Together with the farmers, the ASTA project‚Äôs team selected four varieties in the districts Para and Marowijne for field testing. In the Para district, a trial was implemented to demonstrate innovative production methods for organic pineapples, including demonstrations on modern techniquest and and Good Agriculture Practices (GAP). During the last mission of the international agronomist of ASTA, Mr. Freddy Gamboa, in Suriname a workshop was conducted for government officials. The aim of the workshop was to train government officials on GAP used in pineapple production in the Caribbean and northern and southern America. In total 24 people participated in the workshop, from which 14 females.The project team, in partnership with FairFood International, an international NGO, and Tradin Organic, an exporting company, endeavored to cooperate in the development of a traceability platform and submitted a joint grant application to the RVO, the Government of the Netherlands, but unfortunately, proposal did not make it through the selection process for this year. Nevertheless, this setback has forged a strong partnership that holds promise for fruitful collaboration in 2024, as ASTA team will continue these partnerships to work towards the development and implementation of a platform designed to trace production and delivery for buyers.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, the project established a multi-stakeholder foundation named the Horticulture Innovation HUB, designed to provide long-term support to agricultural producers. A total of 140 farmers, from which approx. 70% women in ITP communities received training on improved pineapple production models, showcasing their economic benefits. In advancing SDG 5, the project provided Gender Capacity Building training to 174 farmers, including both male and female participants. Farmers were trained in leadership inclusion, decision-making, conflict resolution, business skills, and gender equity. A digital platform was developed in collaboration with Dimitra, a global agriculture tech company, to connect pineapple farmers in Moengo, Marowijne, and the four indigenous communities in Para.

2024 Narrative: Implemented to improve seed quality, strengthen food safety compliance, and enhance the overall agricultural regulatory framework.This initiative has had a far-reaching impact, leading to better governance structures, improved market access, and long-term sustainability for Jamaican agribusinesses. By focusing on capacity building, institutional reforms, and industry-wide improvements, the intervention has helped increase agricultural competitiveness, ensure compliance with international standards, and create new opportunities for farmers, researchers, and regulatory bodies. Specifically the Capacity Building intervention led to the training of 25 stakeholders in Quality Control led which enhanced technical skills in seed production and agricultural processing, strengthening overall industry performance. The follow up Plant Breeding Training further resulted in greater innovation and resilience in crop varieties, ensuring that Jamaica‚Äôs agriculture remains adaptive to climate change and evolving market demands.

2023 Narrative: In September 2023, UNDRR held a technical assistance workshop for the City Government of Barcarena (PA) to complete the assessment of the Food Systems Addendum of the Disaster Resilience Scorecard for Cities (tool of the MCR2030 initiative).
2024 Narrative: In November 2024, UNDRR and WFP held a joint workshop for the City Government of Barcarena (PA) to further assess the capacities for climate and disaster resilience of local food systems, via an innovative joint methodology between the two UN agencies. Barcarena now receives technical support to elaborate a Local DRR Plan that incorporates food resilience actions. The workshop served as a pilot and key learnings will feed into a larger-scale UN interagency work in Amazon cities.

Con el prop√≥sito de proveer datos actualizados sobre la situaci√≥n de Seguridad Alimentaria de los hogares salvadore√±os y su capacidad de afrontamiento ante las recientes crisis mundiales y sus efectos en el pa√≠s, FAO a trav√©s del Sistema de Informaci√≥n de Datos en Emergencia (DIEM) y en carta acuerdo con OXFAM Interm√≥n, llev√≥ a cabo la Encuesta Nacional de Seguridad Alimentaria y Medios de Vida (ENSAMv) del 28 de noviembre al 30 de diciembre de 2022.Con el fin de apoyar la disponibilidad de datos de alta calidad, oportunos y confiables en materia de g√©nero, en el instrumento estandarizado para la recolecci√≥n de informaci√≥n del Centro de Datos en Emergencias (DIEM) utilizado para la Encuesta Nacional de Seguridad Alimentaria y Medios de Vida (ENSAMv), se incluy√≥ el √çndice de Toma de Decisiones en el Hogar (HD-MI, siglas en ingl√©s) dirigido a mujeres entre 18 y 49 a√±os de edad que viven con sus parejas, con el objetivo de medir el nivel de participaci√≥n de la mujeres en la toma de decisiones del hogar con respecto al consumo, las opciones reproductivas y otras decisiones, adem√°s de monitorear la participaci√≥n de las mujeres en las primeras tres principales fuentes de ingresos del hogar y si tienen poder de decisi√≥n sobre los ingresos que ganan.2.    WFP ha generado evidencia sobre la situaci√≥n de familias en inseguridad alimentaria, que permitir√° fortalecer la toma de decisiones y la abogac√≠a ante instituciones del estado y cooperantes. Entre los hallazgos relevantes, se encuentran estimaciones de p√©rdidas de cultivos de granos b√°sicos y reducci√≥n en el √°rea de siembra debido a efectos climatol√≥gicos y altos costos de insumos agr√≠colas. Esta evidencia es relevante tanto para el dise√±o de acciones de respuesta humanitaria, como para el dise√±o de estrategias de desarrollo de largo plazo ya que puede ser analizada en conjunto con otros estudios de situaciones anteriores de inseguridad alimentaria. De esta manera se puede comprender la tendencia de la situaci√≥n de seguridad alimentaria de poblaciones vulnerables.3.    Con el fin de contar con herramientas e informaci√≥n para la toma de decisiones de pol√≠tica econ√≥mica y social que tengan en cuenta la perspectiva de g√©nero e identifiquen poblaciones vulnerables, PNUD ha desarrollado tres productos anal√≠ticos: i) un an√°lisis de mecanismos de transmisi√≥n de la inflaci√≥n a nivel local el cual desarrolla un an√°lisis de perspectivas de precios de productos b√°sicos y su incidencia en la econom√≠a nacional; ii) un an√°lisis de micro simulaciones para medir el impacto sobre la pobreza monetaria a nivel de hogar por las variaciones de precio de la Canasta B√°sica Alimentaria (CBA) y iii) un an√°lisis de escenarios macro fiscales y alternativas de financiamiento para la protecci√≥n de las poblaciones en situaci√≥n de vulnerabilidad.
