Sub-Output: UNIDO - Addressing the energy, water, food and climate nexus through organic waste to energy solutions in the Metropolitan Region of Recife
Description: The project is based on an official request of the Government of the State of Pernambuco. It aims to lay the foundation for a larger project to be implemented in partnership with the Government, private sector and with support of international climate finance. The project addresses the sensitive energy, water, food and climate nexus in the Metropolitan Region of Recife (RMR) by promoting the use of organic waste to energy solutions (WTE). The project is of cross-sectoral nature and contributes to the implementation of several federal, state-level and urban policies and regulations, such as the Solid Waste Plan of RMR, the State Plan for Solid Residues of Pernambuco, the Recife Sanitation Plan, the Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC), as well as the recently adopted 2050 National Energy Plan with its ambitious renewable energy targets. Solid waste management, water and sanitation, energy security and climate change adaptation are major interrelated concerns of the Metropolitan Region of Pernambuco (RMR), which includes 15 municipalities, provides livelihood for around 4 million people and hosts major industries in the region. The overall objective of the project is to address the energy, water, food and climate nexus by promoting the use of organic waste to energy (WTE) solutions in the Metropolitan Region of Pernambuco (RMR). The project comprises a 16 months preparatory phase, which foresees the development of relevant assessments for two pilot projects and the formulation of a project document for the main phase. The preparatory phase includes the following results: 1. Assessment of the Camaragibe landfill and recommendations for environmental improvement, including the identification of investment opportunities for organic WTE; 2. Assessment of organic WTE investment opportunities (e.g. biogas, biomethane) on the island of Fernando de Noronha; 3. Formulation of a project document for the main phase and mobilization of climate finance for the implementation.
Agencies: United Nations Industrial Development Organization
Contributing partners: #BR Government of the State of Pernambuco
Implementation partners: #BR Funda√ß√£o de Apoio ao Desenvolvimento da UFPE
SDG Targets: 9.2 Promote inclusive and sustainable industrialization and, by 2030, significantly raise industry's share of employment and gross domestic product, in line with national circumstances, and double its share in least developed countries.

Sub-Output: IFAD ‚Äì 2000003598 - Food Security and Nutrition in the Northeast Semiarid of Brazil achieved (Project Dom Helder Camara - PDHC III)
Description:
The project goal is to contribute to reducing rural poverty and food and nutrition insecurity in family farming. Its development objective is to generate more sustainable, biodiverse food systems that strengthen family farmers' resilience to climate change. It seeks to improve income, food security and nutrition by strengthening family farmers' capacities to produce healthy food. It will also seek to reduce gender, generational and ethnic-racial inequalities through access to public policies, technological innovations and resources that promote sustainable, biodiverse and climate-resilient food systems, and contribute to create new jobs and sources of income.

Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: Women will represent at least 50% of the total beneficiaries (45,000 families with activities focused on women). The Project will consider the poverty level and socio-economic characteristics of women subgroups to prioritize those women who are most poor and vulnerable. To reduce the gender gap in the target group, the Project will develop activities aimed at including women, in particular women whose work is invisible, families headed by women, women from traditional peoples and communities, and young women. The PDHC III Project will promote an integrated approach to promoting gender equity in rural areas and strengthening the agency of rural women in the semiarid region, based on the concept that women have a high capacity to change their own reality, to reject imposed patterns and to resist the limitations established by the environment. The Project will use Technical Assistance and training methodologies to achieve these objectives. This includes the Agroecological Logbooks (ALs), an important tool for measuring, valuing, and giving visibility to women's fundamental contributions to the family economy and community development. The Project aims to further reduce challenges of women‚Äôs work through the introduction of social technologies, especially those related to access to water. Rural women will be prioritized in the activity to issue documentation to rural workers and to provide specific gender-sensitive Technical Assistance, and all technical assistance teams will receive gender training.

2022 Narrative: An agribusiness incubator was held to provide training in good agricultural practices and agribusiness skills to sixty (60) persons, particularly women and youth, in Grand Bahama and Abaco islands. Through these trainings new agribusinesses were developed and small agribusinesses were scaled up. Additionally, eight (8) persons were rewarded grants for inputs to increase production within their poultry and beekeeping operations. The methodology of the agribusiness incubator will be adopted by the Ministry of Agriculture and its proposed Department of Agribusiness for future trainings.
2023 Narrative: The agribusiness incubator was concluded ; three beneficiaries were awarded grants to scale up their poultry agribusinesses. The FAO partnered with the GBPA and an additional two beneficiaries were awarded grant funding to scale up their beekeeping agribusiness.

Agencies: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
Contributing partners: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
Implementation partners: Living Water Community
SDG Targets: 1.3 Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable.,2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.
QCPR function: Normative Support; Direct Support/ Service Delivery
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
Preliminary reporting as at the end of Q3-
74 unique Households, numbering 161 individuals received cash assistance to meet basic needs and overcome protection risks, while 341 unique Households, numbering 1,273 individuals received emergency food assistance to address immediate food needs. Completion of distribution to refugees and asylum seekers of Core Relief Items received by UNHCR and delivered to partners in 2021 continued in 2022. UNHCR received a new stock of CRIs in mid 2022, comprising 1,144 kitchen sets, 6,450 sleeping mats and 1,260 solar lamps. At 30 September, 1,025 sleeping mats, 389 kitchen sets and 10 solar lamps had been distributed either directly to refugees, asylum-seekers and host (local) community members or to partner NGOs to distribute
2022 Narrative: 117 unique Households, numbering 257 individuals received cash assistance to meet basic needs and overcome protection risks, while more than 550 unique Households, numbering over 1,900 individuals received emergency food assistance to address immediate food needs. At December 31, 2022, more than 3,400 Core Relief Items (sleeping mats, solar lamps, blankets, kitchen sets) had been distributed by UNHCR and partners, and more than 100 hygiene kits to refugee, migrant and host community families and people in need
2023 Narrative: UNHCR has continued to strengthen the use of cash-based interventions (CBI) as a priority assistance modality based on both global recommendations and findings of Post-Distribution monitoring. In Trinidad and Tobago, UNHCR implemented multipurpose cash-based interventions, in partnership with Living Water Community and other case management partners, to support 239 individuals to meet their basic needs and overcome protection risks. UNHCR and partners also continued close coordination to strengthen referral pathways and complement the provision of CBI. UNHCR also continued to co-chair, with UNICEF, the national Cash Working Group where discussions on joint market scoping and updates to Minimum Expenditure Baskets were advanced.

The assessment detailed the type of meteorological and hydrological data in Suriname and the location of data collection stations. The review noted that data-gaps exist in the data sets, which can affect robust climate change assessments; however international data platforms can be used to supplement local data.

2023 Narrative: Consultant onboarded to implement an e-commerce pilot project with the Rural Agricultural Development Authority in Manchester to contrubute to improved access o digotal services in agriculture
2024 Narrative: The project aimed to improve digital access and knowledge-sharing among farmers in the Mile Gully extension area (Manchester, Jamaica). It sought to address information gaps, enhance technological adoption in agriculture, and foster collaboration between farmers and the Rural Agricultural Development Authority (RADA).Two workshops held at the Golf View Hotel in Mandeville brought together 40 farmers to engage with the Digital Services Platform (DSP) and explore its customizable themes, practical applications, and potential benefits for agricultural productivity. The key activities undertaken were the Identification of challenges facing farmers in accessing agricultural information; the Introduction of farmers to the Digital Services platform and demonstrating its usability; Providing hands-on training in using the platform; Reviewing and incorporating the crop calendar, focusing on seven crops to help farmers with planning and decision-makingThis initiative also aimed to bridge the digital divide in agriculture, equipping farmers withmodern tools to enhance their farming practices.

Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: Central Emergency Response Fund
Implementation partners: United Nations World Food Programme
SDG Targets: 1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.
Geography: Clarendon; Saint Elizabeth	; Saint Andrew; Saint Thomas	; Kingston; Saint James	; Westmoreland; Trelawny; Hanover; Portland; Saint Catherine; Saint Ann	; Saint Mary	; Jamaica
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2024 Narrative: Unconditional Cash-Based Assistance Programme ‚Äì Beryl Cash Assistance ProgrammeBuilding on previous investments in social protection, WFP supported the Ministry of Labour and Social Security in strengthening Jamaica's social protection system through the provision of cash assistance to populations affected by Hurricane Beryl.WFP fundraised US$ 2.8 million for the emergency in Jamaica, used on cash transfers and service provision:- US$ 1.4 million from USAID/BHA- US$ 897,000 from the Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF)- US$ 326,000 from Canada- US$ 200,000 from UK FCDOThe programme targetted 11,550 beneficiaries over a two-month period, living in households most severely affected by Hurricane Beryl, as identified through the Jamaica Household Damage and Impact Needs Assessment (JHDINA) and targeting criteria. Utilising Western Union's extensive network of 235 locations, WFP delivered direct financial assistance to 3,489 households that consisted of 10,857 individuals (5,487 women and 5,370 men) with overall transfer value of USD 1.2 million.Priority was given to households that met a specified criteria calculated through a vulnerability score based on data captured in the JHDINA, and further verified during a follow-up phase. WFP prioritised assistance to individuals experiencing near-total (Level 3 damage) or total (Level 4 damage) destruction of their homes, with beneficiaries with a less severe damage (Level 2) considered for assistance based on additional vulnerability criteria, such as the presence of children, elderly individuals, or persons with disabilities within the household.Transfer values were determined according to household size:- Households with 1-2 persons will receive JMD 20,000 (US$ 128).- Households with 3-5 persons will receive JMD 36,000 (US$ 230).- Households with 6 or more persons will receive JMD 50,000 (US$ 320).Beneficiaries were informed of their assistance through mobile messaging, showcasing WFP‚Äôs commitment to leveraging technology for improved communication and transparency. Various additional communication methods, including sealed envelopes and outbound calls were utilised, highlighting WFP‚Äôs dedication to reaching the intended beneficiaries through all available channels. The project also created a strong Community Feedback Mechanism that allowed beneficiaries to share feedback, access timely support, report any issue or seek information about the assistance programme.The first round of cash disbursements, which started on September 12 and concluded on October 18, 2024, targeted 3,415 beneficiary households. By the end of the round, 3,156 households redeemed their assistance, achieving a 93% redemption rate. A total of JMD 93,350,000 (USD 685,197) was disbursed during this phase.The second round, which started on October 28, 2024 and concluded on January 18, 2025, expanded the caseload to 3,489 households, including the incorporation of 333 newly eligible households identified through additional assessments. A total of 3,418 households redeemed their assistance, reaching an redemption rate of 98%. Disbursements for this round totalled JMD 119,530,000 (USD 767,292.58).Promoting Accountability Through a Community Feedback MechanismIn parallel with the cash transfer programme, WFP established a Community Feedback Mechanism (CFM) to foster accountability and transparency. This system enables beneficiaries to provide feedback, raise concerns, ask for data information change, seek support and offer suggestions, aligning with global Accountability to Affected Populations (AAP) standards. The CFM infrastructure included transferring tablets to the Jamaica Office, purchasing SIM cards for calls, creating a dedicated email line, and employing four monitoring assistants to manage a helpline at the UN Common Premises. Throughout the programme‚Äôs implementation, WFP worked closely with the MLSS teams at parish level to ensure that all efforts were made and maximized to reach beneficiaries for delivery of cash assistance.During the first payment period, the CFM hotline handled nearly 3,450 calls, comprising over 1,585 inbound calls and more than 1,865 outbound calls. During the second payment period, the CFM hotline handled approximately 9,054 calls, including over 5,090 inbound and 4,059 outbound calls. In addition, the team successfully managed more than 60 emails from beneficiaries.

The SPARS in Guyana entails a five-year implementation plan by the Ministry of Agriculture (MoA), and incorporates all agricultural agencies' activities linked to the generation and production of agricultural data. 2022 Narrative: Agricultural entrepreneurs across the Kingston Metropolitan region, including Denham Town and Hannah Town have had their capacities strengthened in developing and managing their businesses. Two cohorts of trainees have been engaged in both theoretical and field-related trainings. In the first cohort, 75 beneficiaries, primarily women, between the ages of 19 and 69 participated in training and completed business plans. This was critical to helping them understand how to utilize existing information to make financial forecasts as well as develop plans for scaling up their operations. The second cohort also included 75 beneficiaries, primarily youth, who were engaged in trainings geared toward business incubation and overall entrepreneurial development. The capacity built will go a far way in helping the trainees in improving their current activities and in assisting others within their homes and communities.
2023 Narrative: Incubators-  Junior Achievement Jamaica and MAIA Foundation, undertook  training and graduation ceremonies with their beneficiaries; Beneficiaries also received well needed inputs for their enterprises;

2022 Narrative: Capacity development for Laboratory technicians, Quality control managers, Research Officers, Marketing and Extension Officers, Produce Inspectors, and students and staff of the University of Suriname through hands-on training in laboratory techniques and methods to measure, analyze and interpret data on various physical and chemical quality parameters of fresh produce, which is. an essential part of the quality assurance programme in a packinghouse handling facility.
2023 Narrative: Mapping of flood areas - In village meetings community mapping was followed to determine the flooded areas in the respective sites. After the initial information gathering, rangers went out in the field to collect GPS points (coordinates of the farms that supposedly were flooded). An initial map per village (5 with the most problems) were produced. With an analysis of the hydrology- overlaying the initial maps, the version was produced as included in the appendices. The next step is to use Radar Maxar imagery to share final versions. Those maps will contribute to inclusion in mobile applications for planning purposes in the future. The location and crop choice to withstand saturated soils. The most interesting information shared by farmers, was that the flooded zones (polygon or concise spots on the maps) also included farms that were saturated, but not necessarily flooded. Those two categories lead to rotting and damages of crops and therefore were combined.Assessment in the villages - The assessment was carried out in the villages of Kwamalasamutu, Curuni, Sipaliwini and Apetina, being that Kwama was the largest one and Curuni the smallest. In addition to semi structured interviews, 10 % of the population participated in an exhausting interview with 1 focus group in all 4 villages. Based on the gender division in farming, women had the majority in the group of respondents. Farming remains a family affair, but the role of the women is distinct.

Description: WFP seeks to ensure that regional and national institutions can meet the immediate essential needs of vulnerable men, women, boys and girls in times of crisis. This will be achieved through strengthening institutional capacity to respond to shocks in areas of WFP‚Äôs comparative advantage, including end-to-end supply chain management, food systems, social protection, vulnerability analysis and mapping, digitalization and digital solutions and innovative disaster risk financing.
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: World Food Programme Multi-donor
Implementation partners: Caribbean Disaster Emergency Management Agency (CDEMA)

Geography: Anguilla (United Kingdom); Grenada; Virgin Islands, British; Dominica; Saint Vincent and the Grenadines; Antigua and Barbuda; Barbados; Saint Lucia; Saint Kitts and Nevis
QCPR function: Direct Support/ Service Delivery; Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Other (including coordination)
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2022 Narrative: WFP maintains the largest response capacity in Barbados with logistics equipment and assets coupled with emergency telecommunications equipment that support a response in any level of event devastation. Emergency response equipment kits have been pre-positioned in Barbados as one of the four CDEMA sub-regional focal point countries, while equipment has also been donated to three countries recently affected by disasters (Bahamas; Dominica; and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines). These assets help to strengthen the response capabilities of CDEMA and include mobile storage units, prefabricated offices, as well as associated equipment such as generators. In 2022, WFP continued to partner with CDEMA to ensure the readiness of disaster management agencies to use emergency response assets in an emergency. Together, CDEMA and WFP facilitated a series of four-day Emergency Response Equipment Workshops for disaster management offices on the use and deployment of the emergency response equipment pre-positioned in the region. This continuation of emergency response equipment training is intended to support hurricane preparedness and is in support of both the CDEMA Logistics Programme and regional preparedness strategies.   In mid-2022, WFP signed of the Memorandum of Understanding with the Government of Barbados and subsequently launched the Regional Logistics Hub and Centre of Excellence. This facility will act as an emergency logistics hub for emergency preparedness and response efforts in the English and Dutch-Speaking Caribbean. Procurement for the civil works is underway and the prefabricated steel structure for the warehouse is already procured and on site in Barbados. It is expected that the first phase to establish the operational hub will be completed in 2023. Lessons Learned:¬∑      In addition to providing emergency response trainings workshops and trainings, annual refresher sessions are needed  to ensure continuous support towards strengthening national emergency capacity response
2023 Narrative: In preparation for the 2023 Atlantic hurricane season, WFP and the the Caribbean Disaster Emergency Management Agency (CDEMA) conducted trainings in emergency humanitarian logistics in  Antigua and Barbuda, and Saint Kitts and Nevis A total of 25 (6 females and 19 males) and 31 (15 females and 16 males) persons were trained in Antigua and Barbuda and Saint Kitts and Nevis respectively.   Antigua and Barbuda benefited from role-based scenario exercises that allowed participation to better apply knowledge to the national context. This has led to a move toward incorporating this approach in future training sessions on emergency logistics.  In Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, staff from the National Emergency Management Organization along with emergency response personnel that make up the Emergency Operation Centre benefited from training in the use and deployment of donated emergency response assets in preparation for the 2023 Atlantic hurricane season. A total of 30 (8 females and 22 males) participants were trained.  As an integral part of the adoption of the CDEMA Logistics System (CLS) by countries, WFP and CDEMA to provide tailored support through training and technical assistance to integrate the system into their national disaster management framework. The CLS is a platform that allows national, regional, and international humanitarian actors to register and track logistics, food, and other assets that CDEMA can call on in an emergency.  St. Vincent and the Grenadines and Dominica, through the National Emergency Management Organisation (NEMO) has advanced in the integration of CLS, supported by WFP and CDEMA to improve data management practices, and develop standard operating procedures for warehousing and logistics.  Under the Technical Agreement with the Saint Vincent and the Grenadines National Emergency Management Office (NEMO), WFP is funding a Logistics Assistant and a Programme Coordinator positions both of whom are supporting NEMO with various preparedness activities/initiatives. The Logistics Assistant has been a key player in supporting NEMO with warehouse inventory and compilation of damage assessment data by census district for impacts from various hazards. e.g., Tropical Storm Bret. The Programme Coordinator facilitated the NEMO Summer School Programme and supported coordination and development of proposals for various events organized by NEMO. WFP is also supporting data collection, analysis and the development of Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for Warehousing and inventory management that will contribute to the Logistics and Supply Chain program.   Work to establish the Caribbean Regional Logistics Hub and Centre of Excellence in Barbados continued in 2023.  Phase 1 of the hub is complete and the second phase to establish the warehousing facility has commenced with a completion date of June 2024. The facility will act as an emergency logistics hub for emergency preparedness and response efforts in the English and Dutch-Speaking Caribbean.  Lessons learned: For the Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Emergency Response Equipment Training, the assessment of equipment conditions across countries demands adequate time, with careful attention from host organizations to secure equipment and minimize damage. It was also recommended that Manuals should be enhanced for easier navigation, including adding lists of parts/equipment names and quantities (Prefab Office) and conversion sheets showing centimeters and feet (MSU). Saint Vincent and the Grenadines CLS training: Having Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) and conducting a 100% stock take is crucial because they signify a shift from reactive approaches to proactive planning. This change serves as a bridge towards adopting systems thinking, a transition that is effectively supported by digital platforms like CLS. CLS Rollout workshops should involve only core warehouse/logistics operations staff, who will later disseminate processes and training to other end users. Cadet forces specialists should be actively and transparently engaged in SOP development and ongoing training as much as possible. SOP workshops should be run separately in advance of these trainings. WFP places significant emphasis on regional partnerships in alignment with Caribbean countries' commitment to regional integration and collaboration. As such, country's financial requirements and funding availability reflect also regional contributions implemented by WFP through its partnerships with regional institutions including CDEMA, CARICOM and/or OECS among others.

Contributing partners: European Commission Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations; Korea International Cooperation  Agency; United States Agency for International Development Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance; World Food Programme Multilateral Fund

2022 Narrative: Main results:In 2022, in addition to providing cash assistance as part of the Government‚Äôs shock-responsive social protection programme to assist vulnerable individuals affected by Hurricane Lisa, in partnership with the Government, WFP also worked on strengthening national capacities for verification process-related logistics; targeting, selection and notification processes; delivery mechanisms; and monitoring to improve the existing systems capacity to respond to shocks and meet the immediate nutritional and other essential needs of vulnerable people. WFP provided financial and technical assistance to the MHDFIPA to strengthen its capacity to execute a cash transfer programme using a digital payment system to assist families directly impacted by Hurricane Lisa in November 2023. Vulnerable persons received cash transfers or top of in-kind support from the ministry through DigiWallet, a digital payment solution in Belize. The use of this digital platform to provide urgent assistance to families increased financial literacy amongst vulnerable groups and facilitated a faster and more secure means of providing urgent assistance to the families that were impacted.Lessons learned:-	Outreach and communication efforts to target populations/beneficiaries of assistance should be increased to ensure timely receipt of support. The government needs to be at the center of this effort to increase its presence and visibility on the ground.-	Further assistance to the Government extensive assistance on monitoring (outcomes and processes), documenting lessons, and incorporating these to continuously improve their systems should be provided to further strengthen national capacity and ensure sustainability and effectiveness of the support.
2023 Narrative: Main results:In 2023, in addition to providing financing as part of the Government‚Äôs shock-responsive social protection programme to assist vulnerable individuals affected by Hurricane Lisa, WFP provided technical assistance on the use of digital payments to MHDFIPA and MAFSE for the provision of cash transfers using an innovative digital payment system. In the first of its kind in Belize, WFP and the government worked with the private sector to use a mobile wallet to deliver immediate relief support in the form of cash to families heavily affected by Hurricane Lisa and tailor this digital solution to additionally enable the use of a mobile voucher (or restricted cash) to support livelihood recovery of small farmers who sustained losses from the hurricane. Although cash and digital payment solutions are already used in the English-speaking Caribbean, this was the first case of the Government using cash for relief assistance and of using a digital payment solution as a mechanism to deliver assistance in the aftermath of a sudden-onset emergency. The use of this digital payment solution immensely increased the government‚Äôs efficiency and cost-effectiveness in delivering social assistance to meet the immediate nutritional and other essential needs of vulnerable people. As a result, NEMO adopted both the use of cash and digital payment solutions for its disaster relief assistance as reflected in the Relief and Supplies Management Plan of 2023. More broadly, in 2023, WFP embarked on a Digital Payment Ecosystem study with the Ministry of Public Utilities, Logistics, and E-governance (MPUELE) who leads the digitalization agenda in Belize to comprehensively review the experiences in the use of digital payment platforms in the country. A User Journey workshop, key informant interviews, focus group discussions, and a digital readiness survey were undertaken with various local partners and programme beneficiaries to map out user experiences and ‚Äòpain points‚Äô with regard to receiving social protection payments, find solutions to issues uncovered, and identify opportunities for partnerships and collaboration as part of a broader effort to explore digital payments for social protection. The study intends to provide Government with meaningful analysis to inform and further support the scale up of the use of digital payment solutions as a viable instrument to deliver government assistance and services both in regular times and in times of crises/disasters with increased efficiency and cost-effectiveness. Lessons learned:(1)	Preliminary findings from the Digital Payment Ecosystem study as well as actual experience from the implementation of Hurricane Lisa cash assistance programs (HLAP with MHDFIPA and HL-RAP with MAFSE) demonstrate interest from the private sector in testing out innovative solutions to address clients‚Äô needs and in partnering with Government (as a major client) to deliver better and faster services to the public, including vulnerable populations. Government of Belize should capitalize on these partnerships to continue improving the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness in delivering services, especially social assistance in times of crises and disasters. (2)	Service providers will also minimize the costs of accessing these services to program beneficiaries. Government can explore ways of partnering with the private sector to address this (e.g., through an incentive system).

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Resilience to Climate Change and Sustainable Natural Resource Management
Outcome: Caribbean people, communities, and institutions enhance their adaptive capacity for inclusive, gender responsive DRM and climate change adaptation and mitigation
Output: BZE 5.4 By 2026, national capacities and systems are enhanced  to develop, integrate and implement multi-sector adaptation, mitigation and DRR solutions, action plans  and strategies
Sub-Output: BZE 5.4.2 National governments in the Caribbean benefit from strengthened food systems in order to increase access to affordable and nutritious food for food insecure populations
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: European Commission Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations; The Joint SDG Fund; United States Agency for International Development Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance; World Food Programme Multi-donor
Implementation partners: Belize Ministry of Agriculture, Food Security, and Enterprise; Belize Ministry of Human Development, Families, and Indigeneos Peoples' Affairs
SDG Targets: 17.9 Enhance international support for implementing effective and targeted capacity-building in developing countries to support national plans to implement all the sustainable development goals, including through North-South, South-South and triangular cooperation.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2022 Narrative: Outcome 5: Caribbean people, communities, and institutions enhance their adaptive capacity for inclusive, gender-responsive DRM and climate change adaptation and mitigation  Agency Highlights from 2022    Supported the linkage of climate risk insurance through the Caribbean Catastrophe Risk Insurance Facility (CCRIF SPC) to social protection programmes .WFP topped up the CCRIF SPC tropical cyclone and excessive rainfall policies worth $100,000. US$ 192,250 in cash assistance was provided to assist vulnerable people impacted by Hurricane Lisa.  Key Focus Areas for 2023Improvement of existing tools to support faster delivery of appropriate interventions in the aftermath of a crisis/shock.Update of shock-responsive social protection SOP that defines processes and actions for preparedness and details on registration, targeting and delivery mechanisms for disaster response.Improvement of payment processes within Belize's social protection system which are more accessible, flexible, cost-effective and can be easily deployed for disaster response.Engagement with Government ministries and social protection actors in an integrated planning mechanism to ensure that adequate and sustainable financing systems for social protection, including for good financial governance are identified and operationalized.Main results:At the regional level, in 2022, WFP in partnership with CARICOM carried out a Food Security and Livelihoods Survey on the state of food security, livelihoods and access to markets related to COVID-19 and the global food price crisis. A total of five rounds of the survey were administered and the final report consolidates data gathered in August 2022, and includes previous rounds of data released in April 2020, June 2020, February 2021 and February 2022 for the purpose of comparison. This edition of the report also included an analysis of cost-of-living impacts including a special focus on farming and fishing livelihoods. One regional summary report along with an updated interactive dashboard was produced. One report was also drafted for Belize and will be published in the first quarter of 2023. Additionally, in October 2022, WFP also facilitated focus group discussions with specific vulnerable groups in Belize, namely, Indigenous communities (Maya and Garifuna), farmers (in Toledo and Stann Creek Districts), and representatives of people with disabilities. A total of 40 individuals participated in the focus group discussions which were intended to gather information on the impacts of the ongoing food and energy crises on livelihoods, spending on food and other essential needs, and the overall well-being of these specific vulnerable groups that were not captured in the survey. Highlights will be documented in the Special Focus of the Belize Country Report, which is expected to be finalized in December 2022.
2023 Narrative: Main results:In May 2023, WFP administered the sixth round of the food security and livelihoods survey on behalf of CARICOM. The survey results revealed that 3.7 million out of 7.1 million people, or 52 percent of the population of the English-speaking Caribbean, remain food insecure. While this is a 10 percent decrease when compared to an August 2022 survey, the results highlighted growing financial hardship and challenges due to the rising cost of living in the aftermath of the pandemic. The surveys continue to play a critical role in informing analysis and decision-making for governments and development partners in the region and have significantly contributed to the current prioritization of the food security agenda. In August 2023, WFP published a country-specific Food Security and Livelihood Survey summary for Belize. According to the report, people continue to experience challenges to their livelihoods due to the current cost of living crisis. Most respondents to the survey reported significant price increases in food, housing, gas, health and fuels and food consumption patterns show challenges with food security in the country. https://www.wfp.org/publications/caribbean-food-security-livelihoods-survey-may-2023  In partnership with the Ministry of Agriculture, Food Security  Enterprise (MAFSE) and the Statistical Institute of Belize (SIB), WFP provided technical support to map the market monitoring processes towards harmonizing efforts to establish a single best-in class system for the country. Such a system should provide timely market information across entire value chains for critical agri-food commodities, from farm to fork, and disseminated at a global scale. This information is important for several reasons including early warning and forecasting, policy tools such as price controls and subsidies that are implementable by the government, attracting foreign and domestic investment, measuring current economic patterns and impact of current policies, and calibrating subsidies and assistance programs for vulnerable populations. In 2023, WFP also initiated its support to MAFSE in developing its National Food Systems Transformation Pathway, which now includes levers on strengthening value chains for local production, expansion of the national school feeding program, and building resilience supported by early warning systems. The policy was presented at the UN Food Systems Summit +2 Stocktaking Moment in Rome in July 2023. Preparation of a multi-ministerial implementation plan of the policy is ongoing with technical assistance form WFP.Lessons learned:(1)   Critical to the progress and success of the policy is continued technical and financial support from relevant UN agencies (FAO, WFP, and IFAD) given current weak Government capacity to move this agenda forward.

Sub-Output: FAO UTF/BRA/085/BRA Brazilian National Policy on Food Security and Nutrition improved and consolidated
Description:
Contribute to the improvement and consolidation of the National Policy on Food Security and Nutrition (PNSAN), strengthening the National System for Food Security and Nutrition (SISAN) in Brazil, focusing on implementing actions and a supply policy aimed at overcoming the extreme social vulnerability of Brazilian population.
Result 1 ‚Äì The National Policy on Food Security and Nutrition (PNSAN) and the National System for Food Security and Nutrition (SISAN) strengthened and consolidated.
Result 2 - The National Policy on Food Security and Nutrition monitored and assessed.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: Brazilian Ministry of Development, Social Assistance, Family and Fight Against Hunger
Implementation partners: Brazilian Ministry of Development, Social Assistance, Family and Fight Against Hunger
SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: The project seeks to expand the participation of family farmers in extreme poverty, rural women, indigenous peoples and other traditional peoples and communities in the social assistance network and in public food and nutrition equipment. Project indicators consider the % of rural women participating in Food Security and Nutrition programs compared to the total number of farmers participating in the mentioned programs.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Project target population are traditional peoples and communities (indigenous peoples, ‚Äòquilombolas‚Äô, artisanal fishermen, and extractivists), through guidance and improvement of rural productive inclusion actions specific to this public.
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: In 2023, the project carried out actions for the improvement of the National Policy for Food Security and Nutrition (PNSAN) and the National System for Food Security and Nutrition (SISAN). The research on the Mapping of Food Security and Nutrition (MapaSAN) was finalized in May 2022, and its data were treated and statistically analyzed so that they can be made available to states and municipalities. The project also made efforts to carry out a diagnosis on the linkages between food banks, donor partners and beneficiary institutions, as well as mapping, characterization and organization of data related to Public Food Security and Nutrition Equipment - EPSANs in Brazil, in addition to the preparation of a Manual for the Implementation of Food Banks. Regarding the Brazilian Food Network, the focus was on improving the services, with actions aimed at the elaboration of the proposal for a Management and Operations Manual for Family Farming Centers, as well as technical subsidies on tax benefits within the scope of food donation programs. Urban and peri-urban agriculture actions were also highlighted by the project, including the Pedagogical School Gardens, with the objective of contributing to the realization of the human right to adequate food and improving food conditions in the school environment. In this sense, the online course 'Management of Pedagogical School Gardens' aimed at teachers is being developed by UTF/BRA/085/BRA, as well as the development of strategies to promote healthy food at school. The project also continued the improvement of policies that expand access to healthy food by the public most vulnerable to hunger. Thus, a study was carried out to update the Intersectoral Strategy for the Prevention and Control of Obesity. In addition, the cooperation between FAO and MDS has supported the implementation of the Intersectoral Strategy for the Reduction of Food Losses and Waste in Brazil, through the formulation of recommendations for its improvement.
2024 Narrative: The project was implemented from December 2013 to June 2024 and was relevant to strengthening the government's technical capabilities, by accelerating and scaling up the implementation of strategic actions for the qualification and expansion of Food Security and Nutrition (FSN) programs and consolidation of the decentralization of the National System for Food Security and Nutrition (SISAN). The project evaluation highlighted the following main achievements: It was possible to guide and encourage the adhesion of states, the Federal District and municipalities to the SISAN, in addition to obtaining progress on the part of the states in the preparation of their FSN plans. Nowadays, all federation units and some municipalities have already joined the system. Through the project, it was possible to implement the FSN Mapping (MapaSAN), a tool that strengthens the monitoring and evaluation of public policies, which consists of identifying and surveying the situation of FSN actions in the states, the Federal District and municipalities to obtain an overview of the policy implementation. The identification of territories in Food and Nutrition Insecurity, the so-called food deserts, was developed through the Mapping of Food and Nutrition Insecurity, targeting people in social vulnerability. These results allowed us to qualify and focus on public policies related to food supply in the country, including the network of public FSN facilities (community kitchens, popular restaurants, food banks or family farming centers). The project supported the management of Food Banks and the structuring of the Brazilian Network of Food Banks. Materials were prepared on food donation in the country, and for guiding actions to rescue quality food suitable for human consumption. Technological initiatives, studies and partnerships with high potential for contribution to the theme were also systematized. Regarding actions aimed at early childhood, within the scope of the project, visit protocols were developed, with an approach to FSN and food education, with the objective of applying it to the Happy Child Program aiming at the identification of the situation of Food and Nutrition Insecurity (INSAN), involving the training of approximately 25 thousand visitors of the program. Traditional peoples and communities (indigenous peoples, quilombola and artisanal fishermen, extractive peoples) were also supported, through guidance and improvement of rural productive inclusion actions specific to this public.

2022 Narrative: In collaboration with the Ministry of Agriculture, Ministry of Health, Department of National Planning and Statistics Unit, University of the West Indies and University Federal de Paran√°, an analysis of individual food consumption data was completed and presented in the Final Report in December 2021. This document provides evidence to inform future nutrition programmes and policies and improve national capacity to collect, analyse, and manage individual food consumption data and information and will assist the Government in better decision-making for national nutrition programme development and implementation. It can be concluded that the analysis of the survey data revealed low energy, macronutrient and micronutrient intakes. The findings demonstrated an underestimation in the reporting of food consumption at the population level for energy and, at the individual level, the majority of the sample (males and females) were considered low reporters. Results obtained prompted additional analysis/evaluation, which is currently being finalized.With the support of the University Federal de Paran√°, a series of two workshops were completed in November 2022. A two-day workshop was conducted to identify areas of improvement in data collection, methods and tools for future food consumption surveys.
2024 Narrative: Saint Kitts and Nevis: ‚Ä¢ Key stakeholders in the Government of St. Kitts and Nevis were assessed and mapped and resources provided to conduct the CoAHD analysis.  ‚Ä¢ Food and nutrition and dietary practitioners were provided with assistance to generate diet quality indicators at population level, including the Minimum Dietary Diversity for Women (MDD-W).

2022 Narrative: This year in Guyana, in partnership with the Government, WFP facilitated the use of digital solutions for registration, vulnerability analysis, delivery mechanisms, monitoring and reconciliation of cash assistance and facilitated training in shock-responsive social protection. In February and May, two surveys were developed for data collection and handed over through KoBo to screen and target beneficiaries from other Public Assistance Programmes. WFP supported the development of a screening tool for beneficiary eligibility developed for the public assistance programmes, with targeting based on the data collected through the surveys. The tool enabled accurate and real-time tracking of beneficiary collection of payments, improving efficiency in public assistance programmes. MHSSS in partnership with WFP jointly conducted an onsite monitoring survey during distributions, and a post-distribution monitoring survey to better understand the quality of service and impact of the cash transfers. Information collected during these surveys was utilized to better inform the design of future social protection programmes in the Ministry.
2023 Narrative: WFP carried out activities to support national efforts in the delivery of social protection programmes that target the most vulnerable. WFP worked alongside the Ministry of Human Services and Social Security (MHSSS) to improve the provision of cash assistance under the government‚Äôs Women Innovation Investment and Networking (WIIN) programme by improving the skills of 2 Ministry staff in beneficiary information management, cash transfers distribution planning, and payment reconciliation. In June, a total of 2 staff members were trained in using MS Excel in preparation for the cash distributions. This support strengthened the government‚Äôs ability to ensure that the right people were selected to receive assistance.

2024 Narrative: In 2024, WFP partnered with the Government of Guyana to strengthen social protection to help shock-affected people in order to protect their access to food and livelihoods. Building on previous investments, WFP focused on advancing national-level partnerships to empower the Government to mobilize humanitarian support more effectively and reinforce social protection mechanisms during crises.A key accomplishment involved a strategic partnership with the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) to understand current digital transformation initiatives for Social Protection in Guyana and identify opportunities for WFP. This engagement was critical for craving out areas where IDB is providing support to the Ministry of Human Services and Social Security, and opportunities where WFP's expertise can complement implementation and scale-up of the digital transformation and monitoring and evaluation strategies to enhance the service delivery, information management, and reporting capabilities of the Ministry. This partnership demonstrates WFP‚Äôs capacity to bring multiple stakeholders together to share information, plan, and support institutions and governments of the region. This achievement underscores WFP‚Äôs commitment to empowering national institutions, enhancing crisis preparedness, and laying the groundwork for sustainable, locally driven social protection initiatives.

Sub-Output: FAO TCP/BRA/3902   Innovation in public policies to promote Healthy and Sustainable Food Systems supported
Description: Public policies to combat food insecurity and hunger, for food supply and the promotion of healthy, resilient, inclusive, and sustainable food systems designed and implemented at the federal level, relying on alliances with subnational instances and civil society organizations. The expected outputs are: 1. 2. Proposal of at least two public policies with an intersectoral approach that contributes to promoting healthy, sustainable, resilient, and inclusive food systems, helping to increase the supply and offer of healthy food for the population in a situation of acute or moderate food insecurity; Formulation, within the scope of the National Food and Nutrition Security System- SISAN, of innovative funding arrangements and payment mechanisms for local Governments and food insecure households to strengthen food and nutrition security policies; 3. Methodology for research on the Brazilian Scale of Food Insecurity - EBIA - established and applied on a municipal scale in dialogue with the methodology used by FAO; 4. Methodology developed and tested to identify and characterize, at the municipal level, the demand for healthy food by the population under food insecurity; 5. Monitoring Strategy of SISAN designed and implemented.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: FAO Technical Cooperation Programme
Implementation partners: Brazilian Ministry of Agricultural Development and Family Agriculture; Brazilian Ministry of Development, Social Assistance, Family and Fight Against Hunger
SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: Part of the TCP's deliverables (technical studies) will give a distinguish focus to how to expand access of food security and nutrition policies and programs to women and girls.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: The TCP project will deliver technical inputs aimed at improving the access of marginalized populations to social protection policies, specifically food security and nutrition programs and initiatives. In that sense, different stakeholders will be consulted for the preparations of the inputs. Additionally, FAO will involve not just the government counterpart but civil society instances that deal with FSN directly, such as CONSEA, academia, and others to guarantee a holistic view and approach for the project's implementation strategy.
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2024 Narrative: In 2024, subsidies were delivered for building the National Food Supply Plan, as established by Decree N¬∫ 11 820/2023, in close collaboration and supervision of the managing body of the National Food Supply Policy (PNAAB). The methodology approved by the PNAAB Management Committee was followed and extensive consultations with the agents and strategic actors involved in the food supply were considered. These consultations and dialogues were fundamental to contemplating the different areas (production, marketing, access to food), the diversity of actors (family farming, urban agriculture, artisanal fishing, private retail and wholesale marketing agents, non-governmental and community organizations, and consumers) and the territorial particularities in interface with food supply. These dialogues also served as a way of identifying the special needs of traditional people and communities and people with special food needs.The Monitoring Strategy for the National System for Food Security and Nutrition (Sisan) was designed and will be discussed in 2025.The mapping and diagnosis of Solidarity, Community and Emergency Kitchens was carried out, based on the floods resulting from the climate disaster of May 2024 in the state of Rio Grande do Sul, resulting in a set of guidelines aimed at contributing to the formulation of public policies and the generation of more effective management practices in context of crises and catastrophes.

Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations

The country office gender focal point and the gender regional team from RLC will provide technical guidance to ensure that each project adequately mainstreams a gender approach to its main objective. Yet, a concrete gender approach for each project is yet to be defined jointly with the government during the design of the ProDocs.

2023 Narrative: Project supported the preparation of the UTF project which aims to support the National Supply Company (CONAB) to implement the National Food Supply Policy (PNAAB) and outline the National Food Supply Plan.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, assistance was provided to the Brazilian Government to prepare project proposals on Food Security and Nutrition and Productive Insertion. Besides the project with the National Food Supply Company, two new proposals are under preparation with the Ministry of Social Development, Social Assistance, Family and Fight Against Hunger and the Ministry of Environment and Climate Change to support the National Policy on Food Security and Nutrition and to promote the sustainable use of agricultural biodiversity and natural resources.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Equality, Well-Being and Leaving No One Behind
Outcome: People in the Caribbean equitably access and utilize universal, quality and shock-responsive, social protection, education, health, and care services
Output: MSDCF 4.2: Social protection insitiutions have increased capacity and strengthened systems to improve adaptive responses, reduce poverty and enhance resilience, with UN support
Sub-Output: JAM: Vulnerable populations in Jamaica benefit from strengthened social protection systems that reduce poverty and vulnerability,¬† boost resilience and provide assistance to shock-affected people in order to protect their access to food and livelihoods.
Description: WFP seeks to ensure that regional and national institutions can meet the immediate essential needs of vulnerable men, women, boys, and girls in times of crisis. This will be achieved through strengthening institutional capacity to respond to shocks in areas of WFP‚Äôs comparative advantage, including end-to-end supply chain management, food systems, social protection, vulnerability analysis and mapping, digitalization and digital solutions, and innovative disaster risk financing.
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: European Commission Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations; Global Affairs Canada; United States Agency for International Development Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance; World Food Programme Multi-donor
Implementation partners: Jamaica Jamaica Ministry of Labour and Social Security
SDG Targets: 1.3 Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable.,17.9 Enhance international support for implementing effective and targeted capacity-building in developing countries to support national plans to implement all the sustainable development goals, including through North-South, South-South and triangular cooperation.
SDG Goals: 1 No Poverty; 17 Partnerships for the Goals
QCPR function: Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing; Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Data Collection and Analysis
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2022 Narrative: WFP‚Äôs work on capacity strengthening provides support to regional and national institutions to strengthen social protection systems to respond to shock ensuring that the immediate essential needs of the vulnerable can be met in times of crisis.   WFP Caribbean‚Äôs capacity strengthening programme includes regional learning, knowledge exchanges and training efforts. In 2022, WFP continued to engage in workshops, trainings and knowledge transfer on shock-responsive social protection in Jamacia in collaboration with the Ministry of Labour and Social Security (MLSS) with the aim to enhance national social protection systems to increase their capacity to provide assistance to shock-affected people. Trainings on the Jamaica Household Disaster Impact Assessment Tool for social workers (41 participants), and a 3-day data preparedness training were held for units within MLSS on data collection, analysis, and visualization to support the digital deployment of the Jamaica Household Disaster Impact Assessment Tool. Eleven (11) persons participated in the training which was aimed at supporting post-disaster household assessments to help inform for post-disaster social protection mechanisms. Of note, MLSS has taken on board the training provided on data collection utilizing the electronic version of the JHDINA data collection tool and work has begun for the Ministry to integrate the utilization of the electronic form and supporting technologies as part of its business processes.   Fourteen (14) persons from Ministry of Labour and Social Security and Office of Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management (ODPEM) benefited from a two-part webinar on shock responsive social protection. Seven females and two males represented MLSS and five females represented ODPEM. The webinar used scenario-based learning to equip the participants with knowledge on how to strengthen social protection systems through preparedness measures. This will in turn improve technical competencies to design and implement shock-responsive social protection programmes to support people impacted by the shocks and disasters.   In Jamaica, WFP has continued to work with the Government of Jamaica to pursue new payment modalities by testing digital payments to improve service delivery and reduce transaction costs of cash assistance. The use of digital payments can help promote financial inclusion and economic empowerment of the most vulnerable and provide people payment options for a more tailored and improved payment experience. As part of its earlier cash assistance programme, WFP and the Ministry of Labour and Social Security put in place a tailored dashboard to enable tracking and support follow-up and reporting. In November, WFP administered a digital readiness survey targeting retailers and vendors in Jamaica to assess their readiness and capacity to facilitate digital payments to beneficiaries. By collating data from more than five hundred vendors and retailers across Jamaica, the survey findings will be utilized to inform government strategies as part of efforts to widen adoption of digital technologies for social assistance payments moving forward. WFP has used a user-centred approach to identify needs to help facilitate future payments pilots or payment scale ups by developing user centred-recommendations for future programming. The agency has identified existing gender disparities and inequities in terms of service availability, access and use, to inform solutions that are responsive to women‚Äôs differential backgrounds, needs and lifestages through focus group discussions and key informant interviews that took place in 2022. The research to date has been crucial for advocacy with private sector providers and governments to take gender and other factors into consideration when shaping programmes and products to facilitate increased access and use of digital finance solutions Indeed, gender considerations identified through focus group discussions and key informant interviews will be factored into the design of the testing of new payment modalities in Jamaica.      WFP provides support within the region by leveraging its operational capacities to provide common services to government and humanitarian partners in coordination with CDEMA in the event of an emergency as needs are identified.   In 2022, WFP continued to advance supply chain management and emergency logistics at the regional and national levels, supporting CDEMA‚Äôs capacity to manage a well-coordinated, rapid, and efficient response. WFP supported CDEMA‚Äôs logistics capacities by embedding two logistics specialists in CDEMA and one logistics associate based in Jamaica at the Office of Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management (ODPEM). The secondee placed by WFP into ODPEM contributed to the development of draft document for National Logistics Plan and Policy and to a document that government Inventory Management procedures for ODPEM.
2023 Narrative: In 2023 WFP continued to work with the government of Jamaica to strengthen social protection systems to better meet the immediate essential needs of vulnerable people and households in times of crisis. WFP provided technical support to the Ministry of Labour and Social Security (MLSS) for onboarding, piloting and utilization of digital technologies to modernize programme delivery of key components of shock-responsive social protection, including targeting, information management, coordination and delivery mechanisms. At the end of 2023, MLSS was in process of establishing a dedicated server to facilitate the management of data and information for beneficiary intake and registration for future interventions.  Building on previous assistance to test the use of digital payment modalities to deliver social assistance in 2022, in 2023, WFP continued to provide assistance to the government to conduct research on the country‚Äôs digital financial ecosystems, to identify challenges and further explore opportunities in the digital space. In August, findings from the research were launched during a half-day session convened by the Planning Institute of Jamaica (PIOJ) with participation from MLSS. The research provided the Government with analysis on the current state of the digital financial ecosystem with the view of exploring the use of digital payment modalities for improved social protection delivery and rapid scale-ups in emergencies. The findings from this research are also expected to help to shape a more gender-responsive approach to strengthening social protection in the country.  WFP Caribbean‚Äôs capacity strengthening programme includes regional learning, knowledge exchanges, and training efforts. In August, WFP conducted training on shock-responsive social protection in Jamacia. A total of 25 individuals were trained from the MLSS and the Office of Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management (ODPEM). Participants were trained in shock preparedness and response and benefitted from peer-to-peer exchange to foster innovative strategies for linking social protection to disaster risk management. Additionally, a Shock-Responsive Social Protection and Action Planning Workshop was convened with 25 participants from MLSS and ODPEM during a four-day session (14 to 17 August 2023) with the inclusion of a half-day action planning component, which will inform future technical assistance activities and priorities with government.   In addition, and as part of its work to test new digital payment modalities, WFP supported the MLSS with the training of 25 enumerators (16 females and 9 males) on data collection using the KoboCollect data collection application. Training took place in three parishes (Hanover, St Catherine and St Elizabeth) and was utilized as preparation for initial targeting and beneficiary registration among 1,618 individuals in three parishes. In follow-up to this phase of targeting, WFP provided additional training to 22 enumerators (15 females and 7 males) in November ahead of in-person interviews to be conducted by MLSS in late November and early December. These in-person interviews were conducted among XX households and will be utilized to inform targeting among most vulnerable individuals for a pilot initiative to test new digital payment modalities.  WFP places significant emphasis on regional partnerships in alignment with Caribbean countries' commitment to regional integration and collaboration. As such, country's financial requirements and funding availability reflect also regional contributions implemented by WFP through its partnerships with regional institutions including CDEMA, CARICOM and/or OECS, among others.

Description: Support the Ministry of Heath and CARICOM regional bodies to develop necessary policy and standards infrastructure to implement front of package labeling. The evidence and experiences in the Americas show that the best performance is achieved with detailed, text-based nutritional warnings with contrasting letters, located on the display side of the package, visible to the consumer, preferably near the top, separated from other elements of the label on a white background, offering clear, accurate, simple, and brief information about processed and highly processed products that contain excessive amounts of sugar, fats, and/or sodium. The support will also undertake research to determine the most suitable labeling for Jamaica.

2022 Narrative: Through a joint UN Blue Economy project FAO supported the identification and development of options to address financing constraints that project developers face in the fisheries and aquaculture sectors in Barbados, Grenada, and St Vincent and the Grenadines. Key policy, regulatory, economic and capacity constraints, as well as opportunities for the financing of Blue Economy projects focused on fisheries and aquaculture were also identified. A first draft report is being reviewed of key principles for a Public and Private sector Blue Economy Finance strategy for fisheries and aquaculture, as well as finalization of National frameworks to identify, assess and prioritize blue economy fisheries and aquaculture investments. FAO is working with PUNOs to finalize a recommended pipeline for the three target countries. Additionally, a 3-day virtual course is currently being developed, which will explore trade and the blue economy governance, the level of integration of  national and regional development plans and avenues for yielding substantial opportunities and benefits to SIDS such as CARICOM. GCP/SLC/221P/GFF (REBYCIII): The FAO-GEF project preparation grant inception workshop for the project 'Strategies, technologies and social solutions to manage bycatch in tropical Large Marine Ecosystem Fisheries (REBYC-III CLME+)' was held on 28 April 2022, afterwhich the main sections of the project document were drafted and are being reviewed. |The validation workshop planned for January 2023. Progress of the results is estimated at 60%
2024 Narrative: Barbados:‚Ä¢ FAO continued to support circular blue economy in Barbados. Capacities for optimizing fish silage utilization and the developed of sound business models for silage and feed production are ongoing. Women's cooperatives and youth groups will be supported with organizational development and facility upgrading in 2025.

2022 Narrative: Saint Lucia:FAO facilitated access to healthier diets and meals from local sources and enhanced the National School Feeding Programme (NSFP) impacting 7,677 students nationally.An action plan was completed and will contribute to the revision of the policy framework for the NSFP. This plan has been costed and submitted to cabinet for approval. Primary school menus were revised to incorporate more locally grown commodities and improve the nutritional content and acceptance by students. Training was provided to 115 cooks on the use of these materials and menus. Kitchen equipment was also procured for 6 schools to improve infrastructure to facilitate food quality and safety directly impacting 1,500 children.A rapid assessment of the supply chain and logistics of products of the NSFP was undertaken to support the enhancement of a Public procurement mechanisms improving the offer and supply of locally produced goods to the NSFP. At least 40 certified farmers and 3 co-operatives will be contracted to sell produce to the St. Lucian Marketing Board which would be purchased by respective schools. Farmers Field School manuals were also updated providing clearer guidelines for the production of safe nutritious foods.School gardens needs assessments were carried out accros the 6 schools to determine suitable schools to participate in the school garden project and list of garden equipment required. In addition, a student field school activity book and an activity book for school feeding programme in Saint Lucia were developed.Progress of the results is estimated at 50%.Saint Vincent and the Grenadines:FAO facilitated access to healthier diets and meals from local sources and enhanced the National School Feeding Programme (NSFP) impacting some 13,000 students nationally.  A socio-economic analysis will be completed early 2023 to contribute to the revision of the  policy framework for the NSFP. Menus of all of the primary schools were revised to incorporate more locally grown commodities and improve the nutritional content and acceptance by students. Training was provided  to school cooks on the use of these materials and menus. Technical assessments were completed in 8 primary schools which resulted in the procurement of kitchen equipment for 6 schools to improve infrastructure to facilitate food quality and safety and 4 schools will also be provided with suitable eating areas. A rapid assessment of the supply chain and logistics of products of the NSFP is being undertaken to support the enhancement of a Public procurement mechanisms improving the offer and supply of  locally produced goods to the NSFP. 70 farmers have been trained in agri-business methods to improve their capacity to supply the NSFP. Progress of the results is estimated at 60%.
2023 Narrative: St. Vincent and the GrenadinesFAO continued its support for healthier diets and meals from local sources and the enhancement of the National School Feeding Programme (NSFP) impacting some 13,000 students. Some 57 farmers and fisherfolks graduated from a training programme aimed at enhancing capacities to meet the requirements to supply locally produced commodities to the national food feeding programme. Areas covered included food safety, compost production, post harvest management, irrigation, small scale agriculture and agribusiness management.Saint LuciaSaint Lucia's participation in the 14th international conference in Brazil underscored the transformative impact of the Brazil-FAO International Cooperation Programme on the country's school feeding initiatives. This collaborative learning environment, supported by Brazil-FAO cooperation, empowered Saint Lucia to reflect on achievements and enact impactful school feeding laws, with a focus on integrating family farmers. The country's active engagement in the RAES Network since 2018 reflects its commitment to aligning school feeding initiatives with the UN Decade of Action on Nutrition and the Sustainable Development Goals. This work not only addresses immediate nutritional needs but also contributes to shaping the future trajectory, ensuring that school feeding remains a cornerstone in the country's strategy for sustainable development and poverty alleviation, as proposed within the G20 framework for a Global Alliance against Hunger and Poverty.Additionally, Saint Lucia participated in the international technical mission and school feeding course in the Dominican Republic, organized under the same program, Saint Lucia, along with representatives from ten other Caribbean nations, gained invaluable insights into implementing effective school feeding policies. "100% achieved in 2023
2024 Narrative: Saint Lucia and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines‚Ä¢ The Diet Quality Questionnaire was adapted for CARICOM, and stakeholder mapping for CoAHD analysis was finalized, enhancing capacity for food security and nutrition assessments. Training on FIES data collection was completed, enabling improved food insecurity tracking in Caribbean NSOs. Ôªø

2022 Narrative: Capacities of two Ministry of Health officials from Barbados were strengthened on food safety risk assessment of residues of veterinary drugs in food. Due to travel restrictions by COVID-19 pandemic, a series of 11 webinars were held during an 18-month period covering an extensive technical programme. A final face-to-face workshop was held on 15-17 November 2022 in Chile to allow for the necessary in-depth technical discussions and guide participants in applying the methodology used by JECFA to evaluate residues of veterinary drugs. FAO also facilitated a gap analysis and the development of an upgrading strategy for existing food traceability systems, including the interaction with the food safety recall and withdrawal procedures. The outcome supported the intention of Barbados to strengthen measures to export fish commodities to the European Union (EU), the United Kingdom and other markets and to maintain exports to the United States and Canadian markets. A national TCP project for Barbados entitled 'Building Blocks for Food Systems Transformations in Barbados' has been formulated and submitted to RLC for review and approval. The project aims to support the government of Barbados in the establishment and operationalization of the Barbados Agricultural Health and Food Control Agency (BAHFCA), and also include simulation exercise for coordination and management of a food safety situation.Progress of the results is estimated at 40%
2024 Narrative: Barbados‚Ä¢ Initial commitment was secured from the GoB on the purpose and process for the implementation of the Food Safety Control Systems Assessment. 24 officials from across the public and private sectors were trained in the collection of data and on the assessment tool‚Ä¢ Caribbean Food Safety Task Force was revitalized and agreed on food safety priorities including training; updating of legislation; greater collaboration in CODEX. Continued support was provided for Food Control System Assessment to promote transparency and coherence in food safety regulation.‚Ä¢ FAO supported the Caribbean Plant Health Directors and RPPO on planning and coordinating phytosanitary capacity development.‚Ä¢ Assessments completed for animal disease emergencies and training provided for prioritized issues. A workplan is under implementation for expanding the animal identification traceability system to SLC countries. Awareness raised on the feed safety issues related to the use of BSF.‚Ä¢ Approval of Pandemic Fund project in November 2024 which will advance intersectoral One Health planning and surveillance and strengthened diagnostic capacities in the sub-region.
