2021 Narrative:
Preliminary reporting as at the end of Q3-
As one of CDDEMA's sub-regional focal point countries, Trinidad and Tobago benefitted from Emergency logistics equipment training to strengthen national team to deploy with equipment (MSUs, prefab offices, generators, etc.) before hurricane season. This practical training allows participants to be ready to participate in an emergency response in Trinidad and Tobago or in neighbouring islands.Trinidad and Tobago continues to beenfit from WFP's support to CDEMA, which has helped to shape the insitutions work in emergency logisitics, including the establishment and roll our of CDEMA's Logistics System, a regional  emergency relief tracking system, and the launch of the Regional Logistics Hub and Centre of Excellence - a facility that will serve the region as a central hub for humanitarian response in times of emergency; and be the centre for training emergency professionals in the Caribbean

Description: Integrated agriculture land use and ecosystems-based fisheries management planning for a resilient agri-food system; Resilient livelihoods and food security through data, digitalization and sectoral linkages; Feasibility studies to support the development of full proposals to the GCF.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: FAO Technical Cooperation Programme; United Nations Joint Projects
Implementation partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
SDG Targets: 1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,13.1 Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.,13.2 Integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning.
SDG Goals: 1 No Poverty; 2 Zero Hunger; 13 Climate Action

Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights

2022 Narrative: Following the launch of the SDG Fund project, a joint scoping technical workshop was facilitated by FAO and WFP in November 2022 to provide an overview of the Joint Programme and to discuss and share with government entities on other ongoing/planned projects that align with the joint project's scope of work, and any other opportunities for additional support. During the workshop, discussions held included: 1) Building the resilience of farmers, fishers, and vulnerable people, 2) System and institutional capacity improvement of the agriculture and social protection sectors in a risk informed manner and their linkages.The Concept Note for funding under the GCF, entitled 'Integrated climate adaptation and resilience in Dominica' (ICAR) has been revised several times and is currently under review for quality assessment after which it will be submitted to GCF. The project aims to build the country's resilience, with a focus on integration of services for three main sectors: agriculture, health and education.The Agriculture and Food Systems Transformation Roadmap was submitted to the Government of Dominica in September 2021 and has been under review by the cabinet for endorsement. FAO was informed by the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries, Blue and Green Economy that ratification was imminent. The country has requested the total of their TCP allocation be applied to disaster and climate change resilience and natural resource management, aiming to achieve transformative roadmap, through a TCP project proposal currently being finalized (Integrated Agriculture Land Use and Ecosystems-based Fisheries Management Planning for a Resilient Agri-food System in the Commonwealth of Dominica).Progress of the results is estimated at 40%.
2023 Narrative: In 2023, Dominica achieved significant milestones, including the completion of a Spatial Data Mapping and Diagnostics and the revision of the Agriculture and Food Systems Transformation Roadmap. These two critical elements will guide the design of an agricultural geoinformatics system for the Ministry of Agriculture and are to align with the latest priorities of the Ministry, particularly focusing on increasing the agriculture sector's contribution to the GDP. Updated targets and indicators are currently being finalized. In addition, a training workshop was conducted to strengthen the capacity of staff from different Departments on the use of the agricultural geo-informatics system (25 participants: 10 females, 15 males). The piloting of digital decision-support tools for precision irrigation and pathogen risk forecasting is underway. Phase 1, which included site identification and preparation for model development, was completed in July 2023, along with an initial model simulation using proxy data in a virtual machine environment. Once fully operational, these risk management tools and models will be utilized by the extension services. Moreover, progress has been made in raising shock-responsive social protection (SRSP) awareness, linking social protection with disaster risk management, enhancing pre-shock system strengthening knowledge, and sharing best practices for implementing SRSP interventions during emergencies in Dominica. The project proposal (67 Million) for funding under GCF‚ÄØwas submitted‚ÄØwith FAO as one of the implementing agencies, GCF has provided comments which FAO is addressing. It is scheduled to be resubmitted early in 2024. In addition, a USD 15 M CC4FISH2 Subregional project proposal was submitted to the GCF to support Grenada, Dominica, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, and Trinidad and Tobago, which will focus on catalysing systemic adaptation and resilience of fisheries, ecosystems, and communities in the Caribbean to climate change (CC) and disasters through the application of ecosystem-based approaches. A regional fisheries and aquaculture response to emergency (FARE) training was conducted in Grenada in July 2023, where 15 participants (5 women and 10 men) from Grenada, Dominica and Saint Kitts and Nevis enhanced the quality and accountability of preparedness and response to emergencies affecting the fisheries and aquaculture sector. Another regional FARE training was also conducted in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines in November 2023, where a total of 37 participants including 2 from Dominica (15 women and 22 men) were trained. Participants improved their understanding of: 1) relationship between fisheries, aquaculture, emergency, food security and livelihoods, 2) post-disaster damage and needs assessment in emergencies using FAO guidelines for the sector, and 3) best practice responses and standards in emergency interventions in fisheries and aquaculture according to the FAO Fisheries and Aquaculture Emergency Response Guidance including using remote sensing tools.
2024 Narrative: Dominica‚Ä¢ FAO continued to support the government of Dominica toward the finalization of the Agriculture Food Systems Transformation Roadmap, which is expected to be delivered end of Q1 2025. ‚Ä¢ Capacities of drone team built to identify and analyze areas vulnerable to hurricanes, floods, droughts and landslides using drone satellite imagery and expert judgement. Pre and Post disaster assessment protocols developed that integrate drone, satellite and field extension actions.

2022 Narrative: Grenada and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines:The analysis of benefits of risk management practices and technologies will be undertaken through the FMM project to build resilience to multiple shocks and stresses, planning for the implementation of project activities is currently underway.Progress of the results is estimated at 5%.Grenada:A GCF concept note is currently under preparation in consultation with Grenada's NDA, and will be formally submitted in early 2023. The project aims at scaling up Climate Resilient Food and Nutrition Security and Reducing Land Degradation in Grenada.
2023 Narrative: GrenadaEfforts to fortify the agricultural sector in Grenada have been multifaceted, with a focus on enhancing the capacities of extension officers and value chain actors in soursop outbreak preparedness. Special attention has been given to managing pests and diseases to mitigate their impact on farmers' livelihoods. The initiative includes a thorough assessment of pest and disease surveillance, identification, diagnostics, and prevention, with a specific emphasis on quarantine pests affecting soursop.In addition to pest management, strides have been made in incorporating technological advancements into agricultural practices. A training program on drone operation was conducted, complemented by the procurement of drone equipment. Simultaneously, steps have been taken to safeguard the interests of nutmeg and cocoa farmers through the registration for insurance.Moreover, the collaboration between the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and the Government of Grenada continues to seek Global Climate Fund (GCF) support. The objective is to expedite climate change adaptation within the country's agri-food system. Key milestones include the collection of primary data for a pre-feasibility study and the ongoing revision of the GCF concept note.A pivotal component of this comprehensive strategy involves the implementation of a Knowledge Management and Communication System (KMCS). Tailored training sessions have been conducted for end users, administrators, and data suppliers, with a primary goal of facilitating the efficient dissemination of timely information. This encompasses updates on technology, technical insights, market trends, and climate and weather changes. The overarching aim of the KMCS initiative is to bolster decision-making processes, thereby contributing to the strengthening of national food security.As part of a broader strategy, the identification of six pilot sites for assessing climate-resilient technologies and practices is underway. These initiatives aim to address the challenges posed by climate-related factors in the context of food production and security. The strategic selection of pilot sites reflects a proactive approach to implement and evaluate innovative solutions that can effectively mitigate the impact of climate variability on food security.
2024 Narrative: Grenada ‚Ä¢ The resilience of farmers was bolstered by the finalization of an updated Agriculture Risk Insurance Product for Nutmeg and Cocoa and its submission to the Ministry of Agriculture.  ‚Ä¢ A surveillance and emergency response system prioritized for soursop traceability and certification to secure and increase exports, was launched. Pilots have begun, and training materials for Good Agricultural Practices (GAPs) and Integrated Pest Management (IPM) are under development.  ‚Ä¢ The mobilization of resources to improve the resilience of nutmeg agro-forest systems was advanced through the submission of a proposed intervention to GEF which promotes of integrated climate-resilient and biodiversity-friendly nutmeg production and restoration.  ‚Ä¢ TR4 preparedness training equipped 31 officials with skills to tackle fusarium outbreaks in order to safeguard the region‚Äôs banana and plantain industries.- FAO supported the Caribbean Plant Health Directors and RPPO on planning and coordinating phytosanitary capacity development. ‚Ä¢ Assessments completed for animal disease emergencies and training provided for prioritized issues. A workplan is under implementation for expanding the animal identification traceability system to SLC countries. Awareness raised on the feed safety issues related to the use of BSF. ‚Ä¢ Approval of Pandemic Fund project in November 2024 which will advance intersectoral One Health planning and surveillance and strengthened diagnostic capacities in the sub-region.

2022 Narrative: FAO assisted with the enhancement of the strategic framework addresses policy gaps, improving sectoral expertise, and enabling environments for GCF programming. A diagnostic analysis report on impacts of COVID-19 and economic stimulus measures on climate change strategies and plans have been delivered. Initial reports were also completed and including consultations (including a list of opportunities for aligning the country's climate change agenda with the economic recovery agenda) and proposed measures for the agriculture and health sectors to maximize climate economic and social benefits. 44 individuals (61% women) participated in the development of measures proposed for the agriculture and health sectors. A modeling exercise and cost benefit analysis to optimize and prioritize these measures was also undertaken. Following the launch of the SDG Fund project, a joint technical workshop was facilitated by FAO and WFP in November 2022 to provide an overview of the Joint Programme and to discuss and share with government entities on other ongoing/planned projects that align with the joint project's scope of work, and any other  opportunities for additional support. Technical sessions on improving gender-sensitive data for emergency preparedness and response, digital data systems, assessment and national registries of farmers, fishers and vulnerable households, and improving linkages between agriculture and social protections sectors. The project workplan and TORs for the country coordinating committee are currently being developed.A concept note for a subregional Adaptation Fund project has been formulated to build climate resiliency of smallholder farming systems through the adoption of climate-responsive innovations for soil, water and data management. Based on legal parameters of the AF, and if the proposal is accepted, FAO will only take on the role of executing agency.Progress of the results is estimated at 40%

Sub-Output: JAM: Food Resilience Through Community Farming
Agencies: United Nations Development Programme
Contributing partners: Global Environment Facility - Small Grants Programme
Gender marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to gender equality/women's empowerment
2022 Narrative: The Bahamas Red Cross Society‚Äôs ‚ÄúFood Resilience Through Community Farming‚Äù pilot project explores climate resilient farming as a mechanism to improve food security by reducing reliance on food imports. This project is an essential component of BRCS‚Äô Vision 2030 which seeks to address key social and environmental issues. The Bahamas‚Äô vulnerability to the impacts of climate change, results in a population that is increasingly at risk of food insecurity, loss of homes, livelihoods, and dignity. The BRCS envisions a Bahamas with empowered climate-resilient communities. Therefore, our objective is to develop a fully functional, climate resilient demonstration farm on site at BRCS headquarters on JFK Drive on the island of New Providence as an innovative mechanism for improving food security while promoting the importance of a healthy, varied diet to our welfare beneficiaries. The pilot farm will provide a training platform for backyard and small-scale commercial farmers, BRCS volunteers, BRCS youth programme participants and community members. We intend to utilize modern agricultural systems and technologies that increase the production of crops (vegetables, herbs), while using eco-friendly and climate-smart technology to reduce our environmental impact through efficient use of space, water and energy conservation, pollution reduction and conservation of the natural landscape.

2022 Narrative: In 2022, WFP in partnership with CARICOM undertook two rounds of data collection on the state of food security, livelihoods, and access to markets related to COVID-19 and the global food price crisis. A specific report was produced for Barbados and all survey rounds are available on a regional dashboard.  See the link below .https://analytics.wfp.org/t/Public/views/CaribbeanFoodSecurityLivelihoodsImpactSurvey/Overview?%3Aembed=y%3AisGuestRedirectFromVizportal=y  In Saint Lucia, WFP in partnership with the Government carried out a livelihoods analysis which presented a framework to analyze and present the linkages and influences between livelihood groups and their seasonality, resilience, wealth, diversity, and exposure to shocks. Livelihoods profiling, visualization of a seasonal calendar, and zoning contribute to a data-driven approach to inform how social protection programmes can be scalable, responsive and support resilience
2023 Narrative: In May 2023, WFP administered the sixth round of the food security and livelihoods survey on behalf of CARICOM. The survey results revealed that 3.7 million out of 7.1 million people, or 52 percent of the population of the English-speaking Caribbean, remain food insecure. While this is a 10 percent decrease when compared to an August 2022 survey, the results highlighted growing financial hardship and challenges due to the rising cost of living in the aftermath of the pandemic. The surveys continue to play a critical role in informing analysis and decision-making for governments and development partners in the region and have significantly contributed to the current prioritization of the food security agenda. Between August and October 2023, WFP published country-specific Food Security and Livelihood Survey summaries for St Vincent and the Grenadines, Antigua and Barbuda and Barbados. WFP provided technical support to map the market monitoring processes towards harmonizing efforts to establish a single best-in class system in countries such as  Barbados, Saint Lucia and St. Vincent and the Grenadines. Such a system should provide timely market information across entire value chains for critical agri-food commodities, from farm to fork, and disseminated at a global scale. This information is important for several reasons including early warning and forecasting, policy tools such as price controls and subsidies that are implementable by the government, attracting foreign and domestic investment, measuring current economic patterns and impact of current policies, and calibrating subsidies and assistance programs for vulnerable populations.   In Saint Vincent and the Grenadines WFP supported the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry, Fisheries, Rural Transformation, Industry and Labour to digitise government‚Äôs programme of support to farmers. WFP helped to complete a mapping exercise that has led to the creation of a data collection tool and project mapping dashboard. Both tools will provide a comprehensive overview of ongoing projects and allows the Government to improve data management, identify cross-project dependencies, promote linkages with other sectors and establish effective coordination mechanisms. The dashboard‚Äôs use will facilitate evidence-based decision-making and overall contribute to achieving better outcomes in the agricultural sector. Also in development are Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) to introduce a structured framework that streamlines processes, clarifies roles and responsibilities, and enhances data handling processes within the ministry to track project progression, improves financial oversight through enhanced transparency and accountability in budgeting and expenditure. This will, in turn, contribute to improving financial oversight through enhanced transparency and accountability in budgeting and expenditure.  the Ministry of National Mobilisation, Social development  Youth in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines and WFP are working to improve livelihood opportunities for vulnerable people. Initial efforts focused on building knowledge and skills in agriculture, small business and financial management, tools, methods and skills, including how to increase their resilience to climate and other shocks to address the impact of disasters on livelihoods of small holder farmers and other vulnerable people. A total of 1,778 (874 females and 904 males) participants are confirmed to have been trained thus far.  WFP also facilitated and supported the Governments of St. Vincent and the Grenadines and Dominica, to participate in ‚ÄòThe Power of Multi-Sector Approaches for Human Capital Development‚Äù event which was held in Brazil in August 202. The event aimed to chart out pathways to strengthen human capital in the region so that every person can reach their full potential. The Forum offered an opportunity for representatives from across the region to boost multi-sector approaches linking education, food security and nutrition for human capital development, using two complementary approaches: school feeding and social protection systems. The government of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines has since signed onto the School Meals Coalition .

2022 Narrative: Para el per√≠odo de ejecuci√≥n del proyecto durante el a√±o 2022, se puede destacar los logros m√°s relevantes alcanzados por las agencias implementadoras: 1.    Con el prop√≥sito de proveer datos actualizados sobre la situaci√≥n de Seguridad Alimentaria de los hogares salvadore√±os y su capacidad de afrontamiento ante las recientes crisis mundiales y sus efectos en el pa√≠s, FAO a trav√©s del Sistema de Informaci√≥n de Datos en Emergencia (DIEM) y en carta acuerdo con OXFAM Interm√≥n, llev√≥ a cabo la Encuesta Nacional de Seguridad Alimentaria y Medios de Vida (ENSAMv) del 28 de noviembre al 30 de diciembre de 2022.Con el fin de apoyar la disponibilidad de datos de alta calidad, oportunos y confiables en materia de g√©nero, en el instrumento estandarizado para la recolecci√≥n de informaci√≥n del Centro de Datos en Emergencias (DIEM) utilizado para la Encuesta Nacional de Seguridad Alimentaria y Medios de Vida (ENSAMv), se incluy√≥ el √çndice de Toma de Decisiones en el Hogar (HD-MI, siglas en ingl√©s) dirigido a mujeres entre 18 y 49 a√±os de edad que viven con sus parejas, con el objetivo de medir el nivel de participaci√≥n de la mujeres en la toma de decisiones del hogar con respecto al consumo, las opciones reproductivas y otras decisiones, adem√°s de monitorear la participaci√≥n de las mujeres en las primeras tres principales fuentes de ingresos del hogar y si tienen poder de decisi√≥n sobre los ingresos que ganan.2.    WFP ha generado evidencia sobre la situaci√≥n de familias en inseguridad alimentaria, que permitir√° fortalecer la toma de decisiones y la abogac√≠a ante instituciones del estado y cooperantes. Entre los hallazgos relevantes, se encuentran estimaciones de p√©rdidas de cultivos de granos b√°sicos y reducci√≥n en el √°rea de siembra debido a efectos climatol√≥gicos y altos costos de insumos agr√≠colas. Esta evidencia es relevante tanto para el dise√±o de acciones de respuesta humanitaria, como para el dise√±o de estrategias de desarrollo de largo plazo ya que puede ser analizada en conjunto con otros estudios de situaciones anteriores de inseguridad alimentaria. Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way

2024 Narrative: Supply Chain Maturity Model: A Roadmap for Performance Improvement    WFP, in collaboration with CDEMA, developed a supply chain maturity model to systematically assess and enhance logistics performance. Designed as a strategic framework, the tool enables disaster management agencies like NCCR to evaluate national capacities and target critical areas for improvement. By setting benchmarks and identifying systemic weaknesses, the model prioritizes investments and interventions, ensuring resources address bottlenecks and reinforce the supply chain's weakest links. Suriname (NCCR) was the first country where the SCAN (Supply Chain Asssessment Navigator) tool was rolled out. Following a mission and a number of consultations, WFP and NCCR agreeed on the priority areas to be addressed through the subsequent activities.                                                                        Completion of the Regional Logistics Hub   A major achievement in 2024 was the completion of the Regional Logistics Hub, located in Barbados. The state-of-the-art facility will serve as a centralized location for coordinating responses and downstream transport solutions in an emergency. Furthermore, it will provide appropriate warehousing and training solutions designed to both enhance Caribbean emergency preparedness and readiness and provide a facility from which large-scale humanitarian responses could be launched. The facility is a key component of the overall WFP strategy to strengthen the capacity of CDEMA and its Participating States which include Surinamein all areas of emergency supply chain management.‚ÄØ

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Economic resilience and Shared prosperity
Outcome: The Caribbean has fully transitioned to a more diversified and sustainable economy that supports inclusive and resilient economic growth
Output: MSDCF 2.2: National and regional institutions capacity is strengthened to accelerate transition to diversified, resilient and inclusive food systems economies
Sub-Output: REG Harnessing trade policy and transport and logistics to build sustainable and resilient food supply chains in the Caribbean and the Arab region
Description:
Objective of the Project
To strengthen the capacities of selected countries in the Caribbean and the Arab region to leverage trade policy measures and harness transport and logistic to be better prepared for and respond to supply chain disruptions and build sustainable and resilient food supply chains.

Activities
The project will enhance national actions and policy coordination by supporting the development of policies and plans that promote food security and inclusive and sustainable economic growth through sustainable and resilient food trade and food transport and logistics systems. The project will be deployed across three main phases:

Phase 1 will assess the current state of play regarding food trade and food transport and logistics systems. It will also help to identify needs and gaps as put forward context specific recommendations and solutions.

Phase 2 will focus on implementing the recommendations and solutions identified in Phase 1.

Phase 3 will aim to expand regional cooperation in the field of sustainable and resilient food trading and food transport and logistics system. This will ensure wider dissemination of the project benefits within the target regions and beyond.  Outreach and dissemination activities will include dedicated collaborative platforms, consultation mechanisms, and distance learning.
Agencies: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development
Contributing partners: United Nations Development Account
Implementation partners: Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean
SDG Targets: 2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,8.2 Achieve higher levels of economic productivity through diversification, technological upgrading and innovation, including through a focus on high-value-added and labour-intensive sectors.
SDG Goals: 2 Zero Hunger; 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth
QCPR function: Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing; Policy Advice and Thought Leadership; Capacity Development/Technical Assistance

2024 Narrative: Following an overview of school feeding activities in the country, WFP shared a number of recommendations and suggestions with the Ministry of Education, Culture and Science. Based on these recommendations, the Government made officially commitments at the School Meals Coalition https://schoolmealscoalition.org/member/suriname To drive the operationalization of committments, the Minsitry suggested to establish an Inter-Ministerial Task Force. This coordination mechanism is tasked with working on a school feeding policy and designing a pilot school meals programme with a focus on indigenous food systems. To support these initiatives further, WFP convened representatives from the Government, private sector and civil society for exploring scenarios for Amazon food systems. This was done as part of a workshop on Amazon Food Systems in Brazil where all Amazon coutries were representated.

Sustaining peace marker narrative: In an emergency, WFP supports national emergency response efforts to assist affected persons.
2022 Narrative: In Guyana, WFP assisted shock-affected populations through the provision of cash assistance. Assistance is provided through existing government‚Äôs social protection systems targeting those most in need including people with disabilities, single female- headed households, the elderly and other economically and socially marginalized groups. In response to the socio-economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, in March, April and May 2022 the Ministry of Human Services and Social Security in partnership with WFP provided cash assistance to vulnerable people impacted by the pandemic and the 2021 flooding. Recipients of the cash assistance were participants of the MHSSS‚Äô Women Innovation and Investment Network Programme which is geared towards women empowerment through innovation and investment in livelihood activities in the community. The cash assistance complemented the assistance offered by the Government to women to prioritise their households‚Äô needs and be in a better position to take advantage of the opportunities offerered under the livelihoods and business development programme. A total of 8,204 people (of which 4,122 were women) benefitted from cash-based transfers worth US$ 548,553.
2023 Narrative: Since 2021 the Ministry of Human Services and Social Security‚Äôs Women‚Äôs Innovation Network (WIN) programme has empowered women and girls by building and enhancing knowledge and skills for improved economic participation. WFP has supported the programme since its pilot phase and continuing from successive years, in 2023, the agency partnered with the MHSSS to provide cash support valued at a total of USD 80,742 to a select cohort of 817 people. This programme adapts to the needs of the country, generating entrepreneurs who are knowledgeable in a variety of technical vocational areas and are better equipped to seek upward mobility opportunities.Results from an onsite monitoring survey revealed that 27 percent of the beneficiaries that received cash, owned food businesses, of which 25 percent are Agri businesses. The support provided by WFP helped beneficiaries to meet their critical needs as well as facilitate investments in livelihoods and increase empowerment in women and girls. Overall, 64 percent of beneficiaries were very satisfied with the assistance received.

Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
Preliminary reporting as at the end of Q3-
523 VoTs and Venezuelan migrants received food assistance in July and September
2022 Narrative: 1620 VoTs and Venezuelan migrants received food assistance in 2022
2023 Narrative: IOM continues to support vulnerable migrant families and victims of trafficking in meeting their core needs, especially in relation to food, through the donor-funded projects of ASC and RMRP. According to the DTM, food continues to be a top priority need and according to the WFP, 97% of respondents reported higher than usual food prices in the August 2022 Caribbean Food Security  Livelihoods Survey. Therefore, in 2023, IOM supported 864 families (3,585 beneficiaries) with food in Trinidad and Tobago through cash-based interventions, specifically through the provision of food vouchers from supermarkets within various communities. In 2023, given the rising costs of food and that food remained a top priority, funding was reallocated to increase the reach of such activities. Beneficiaries were referred by civil society, the Diplomatic Corps, other UN agencies, and by Government entities (CTU and CA), however, the vast majority were self-referrals. Beneficiaries were screened using an Emergency Assistance Screening Form and/or the Beneficiary Needs Assessment Form to determine their eligibility for food assistance. A major implementing partner in these activities includes the Archdiocesan Ministry for Migrants and Refugees.
2024 Narrative: Providing food support to 3,066 beneficiaries in Trinidad and Tobago through cash vouchers for supermarkets, including those in rural areas, highlights IOM‚Äôs commitment to addressing food insecurity among vulnerable populations. The use of grocery vouchers empowered beneficiaries to make their own food choices, promoting dignity and autonomy. By focusing on rural communities, IOM along with its Implementing Partner, the Archdiocesan Ministry for Migrants and Refugees, ensured assistance reached underserved areas, demonstrating an inclusive approach. The careful screening of beneficiaries ensured aid was directed to those most in need, maximizing the impact of resources. Establishing feedback mechanisms further emphasized accountability and a commitment to continuous improvement, allowing beneficiaries to share their experiences and ensuring the support aligned with their specific needs.

Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations

LNOB groups targeted: Women & Girls; Peasants & Rural Workers; Youth
2022 Narrative: FAO supported the formulation of a structured approach for developing a national e-agricultural strategy (for Barbados, Dominica, Grenada and Saint Kitts and Nevis) and digital hub (for Dominica and Grenada). This initial mapping outlined the necessary policies and drivers, enabling frameworks, digital competitive ecosystem, and governance requirements in existence; the mapping is key to the element of the new e-agriculture strategy. An initial assessment of the digital environment, its characterization and a situational overview was completed, which provided the foundation for the new strategy. Over 100 persons benefited from capacity strengthening on digital promotion, via an online platform. In Grenada, videos were done to promote and enhance linkages to rural tourism in at least one community. The capacity needs assessments and the finalization of the e-agriculture Strategy are expected to be completed in 2023, and will support the acceleration and use of information to streamline informed decision making in the sector.Barbados is also a beneficiary to the CELAC-China-FAO Digital Agriculture initiative which has already contributed to the exchange of experiences including COVID-19 response and recovery policies and programs, and the advancement of food security and nutrition in Latin America and the Caribbean. The development and implementation of digital agriculture and rural development platform and the piloting of digital solutions is expected to be undertaken over the next 2 years.Progress of the result is estimated at 10% (for Barbados); 50% (for Dominica).
2023 Narrative: GrenadaIn relation to digitization, FAO continued to support the MoA initiatives, focused on fostering digital agriculture adoption, and establishing a national innovation hub. Emphasizing public-private partnerships, these initiatives empower youth and women in the agricultural value chain. FAO, in collaboration with UNDP, also backed Grenadian innovators in agro-processing and agro-tourism through the Blue-Green Digital Innovation Challenge, which offered up to US $30,000 in grant funding for MSMEs to implement digital solutions.Saint Kitts and NevisIn alignment with the Department of Agriculture's commitment to digital agriculture solutions, a national e-agriculture strategy has been developed to provide a framework for monitoring and evaluating of the use of digital technologies and solutions and provide additional opportunities to promote best practices models across the sector. It will also offer timely insights to empower farmers in implementing best practices and enhancing farm management. DominicaIn 2023, FAO provided technical support to enhance digital knowledge for the agriculture sector. An assessment of digital agriculture readiness in Dominica through selected value chains was conducted, to support the government of Dominica to strengthen an enabling environment for the adoption of digital agriculture strategies. Views of value chain actors (cassava, taloma and seamoss) were recorded to obtain a better understanding of their needs, challenges and how digital solutions could be helpful in the agriculture context. Community workshops were completed, with a total of 27 participants (17 males and 20 females). Additionally, a situational analysis was conducted to provide information on Dominica's country context for digital agriculture ecosystem framework, national digital technologies framework and digital services portfolio.
2024 Narrative: Dominica and Saint Vincent and the GrenadinesIn in St. Vincent and the Grenadines and Dominica, FAO supported enhanced resiliency initiatives through capacity building and innovative systems. Key achievements include advanced drone training for 38 participants, Climate Smart Agriculture training for 120 stakeholders, and disaster risk management workshops reaching 100+ participants. Digital registries improved data management, while gender-responsive approaches and cross-sector collaboration ensured sustainability, aligning with national priorities and strengthening agricultural and social protection systems.GrenadaÔªø‚Ä¢ A draft proposal developed for the establishment of a Caribbean Extension Learning Platform, in collaboration with UWI, to improve access to quality training and support on climate resilient and sustainable agricultural practices and technologies.Saint Kitts and NevisÔªø‚Ä¢ Initiative launched to provide technical assistance for the design and implementation of a Regional (CARICOM) data exchange platform (database and integrations) based on country AIT systems. ‚Ä¢ The resilience and food security of local communities has been improved by providing capacity building for teams from the Ministry of Agriculture in Drone and Participatory GIS Mapping. ‚Ä¢ A draft proposal developed for the establishment of a Caribbean Extension Learning Platform, in collaboration with UWI, to improve access to quality training and support on climate resilient and sustainable agricultural practices and technologies.‚Ä¢ A knowledge hub on soil and water issues has been designed and platform launched. This information will be used to support reporting under multilateral environmental agreements and decision making for land use planning.

Sub-Output: UNDRR - "Making Cities Resilient 2030" - National Pilot of the Food Systems Scorecard Addendum
Description:
The "Disaster Resilience Scorecard for Cities: Food System Resilience ‚Äì Addendum"  was developed by UNDRR and Baylor University, with the support of FAO and WFP. The tool completes the disaster resilience capacities assessment performed by the Scorecard by delving into food systems resilience and food security issues at the city-level. It covers issues of food production, supplies, transport and services, and assess their integration into disaster resilience governance arrangements, policies and projects. 

In Brazil, the tool was nationally piloted in November 2022 in Porto Alegre (RS).
Agencies: United Nations Office for Disaster Risk Reduction
Contributing partners: United Nations Office for Disaster Risk Reduction
Implementation partners: United Nations Office for Disaster Risk Reduction
SDG Targets: 1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,11.5 By 2030, significantly reduce the number of deaths and the number of people affected and substantially decrease the direct economic losses relative to global gross domestic product caused by disasters, including water-related disasters, with a focus on protecting the poor and people in vulnerable situations.,11.b By 2020, substantially increase the number of cities and human settlements adopting and implementing integrated policies and plans towards inclusion, resource efficiency, mitigation and adaptation to climate change, resilience to disasters, and develop and implement, in line with the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction 2015-2030, holistic disaster risk management at all levels.
SDG Goals: 1 No Poverty; 2 Zero Hunger; 11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
Geography: Porto Alegre; Rio Grande do Sul¬†(RS); Brazil
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to gender equality/women's empowerment
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2022 Narrative: The "Disaster Resilience Scorecard for Cities: Food System Resilience ‚Äì Addendum" was developed by UNDRR and Baylor University, with the support of FAO and WFP. The tool completes the disaster resilience capacities assessment performed by the Scorecard by delving into food systems resilience and food security issues at the city-level. It covers issues of food production, supplies, transport and services, and assess their integration into disaster resilience governance arrangements, policies and projects. In Brazil, the tool was nationally piloted in Porto Alegre (RS) in November 2022, when UNDRR held a series of urban disaster resilience activities in the framework of the Making Resilient Cities 2030 (MCR2030) initiative, with the support of the Municipal Secretariat for Local Governance and Policy Coordination (SMGOV). Porto Alegre's commitment to MCR2030 is part of a wider process of strengthening the metropolitan governance of risks in Greater Porto Alegre, as well as becoming one of the first cities in Latin American to renew its Resilience Strategy (prepared in 2016 with the support of the former-100 Resilient Cities, now Global Network of Resilient Cities and partner of MCR2030). UNDRR's support aimed to accelerate the renewal of the Resilience Strategy with the holding of a two-days workshop to comprenhensively assess the resilience capabilities of Porto Alegre. The activity was attended by representatives of all municipal bodies that make up the Permanent Commission for Emergency Action (Copae), which collectively completed the UNDRR's Disaster Resilience Self-Assessment Tool for Cities (Scorecard), along with its Addenda on food systems and public health. After nearly 200 resilience indicators, participants assessed that the municipality had a solid capacity base for risk management and resilience, as shown in the many resilience actions already being implemented in Porto Alegre. Nonetheless, to use the Food System Addendum, together with its Public Health counterpart, helped Porto Alegre to pinpoint the need for the local government to scale up existing resilience actions, better reach out to all communities, and better integrate public health and food security considerations and actors into the local resilience agenda.The experience in Porto Alegre will serve to replicate the use of the Scorecard's Food System Addendum in Brazil and across the Americas and Caribbean.

2023 Narrative: Since 2018, WFP has partnered with CDEMA to strengthen logistics and supply chain management in the Caribbean to improve the delivery of assistance to vulnerable populations. As part of WFP's efforts to develop the regional supply management system, WFP is providing support to CDEMA for the testing and rollout of CDEMA's supply chain management system, the CDEMA Logistics System (CLS) in participating states. The CLS is a platform that allows national, regional, and international humanitarian actors to register and track logistics, food, and other assets that CDEMA can call on in an emergency.In October 2023, the process to adopt CLS. commenced with a combined foundational logistics and CLS training course where 25 individuals (6 females and 9 males) from several regions of Guyana participated in the event. Participants gained proficiency in the system's use, and the training provided the platform for national-level stakeholders to collaborate on emergency relief management and distribution measures with the Civil Defense Commission.A stock taking exercise was subsequently undertaken to capture emergency stock in the CLS at two government warehouses. The integration and adoption of the system allow the government to modernize and digitize logistics operations in Guyana, an important step in improving the capacity to respond on the ground in an emergency. Beyond initial CLS upload and training, discussions with the government evolved to strategic planning at micro and macro levels to further facilitate the system's implementation. In 2024, tailored support will be provided to the government to further develop the requisite framework to adopt and integrate CLS into their national disaster management systems such as developing the national response plans, objectives, policies, and standard operating procedures.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Resilience to Climate Change and Sustainable Natural Resource Management
Outcome: Caribbean people, communities, and institutions enhance their adaptive capacity for inclusive, gender responsive DRM and climate change adaptation and mitigation
Output: MSDCF 5.4: People vulnerable to food insecurity in the Caribbean benefit from strengthened food systems in a changing climate
Sub-Output: JAM: Vulnerable populations benefit from strengthened end to end supply chain and logistics capacities in order to protect their access to food and livelihoods in Jamaica.
Description: WFP seeks to ensure that regional and national institutions can meet the immediate essential needs of vulnerable men, women, boys and girls in times of crisis. This will be achieved through strengthening institutional capacity to respond to shocks in areas of WFP‚Äôs comparative advantage, including end-to-end supply chain management, food systems, social protection, vulnerability analysis and mapping, digitalization and digital solutions and innovative disaster risk financing.
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: European Commission Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations; United States Agency for International Development Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance; World Food Programme Multi-donor; World Food Programme Multilateral Fund
Implementation partners: Jamaica Jamaica Ministry of Labour and Social Security
SDG Targets: 17.9 Enhance international support for implementing effective and targeted capacity-building in developing countries to support national plans to implement all the sustainable development goals, including through North-South, South-South and triangular cooperation.
QCPR function: Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing; Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Data Collection and Analysis
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2022 Narrative: In May 2022 in partnership with CDEMA, WFP jointly facilitated a four-day emergency logistics equipment workshop for disaster management offices on the use and deployment of the emergency response equipment pre-positioned in the region. Emergency response equipment kits have been pre-positioned in the four CDEMA sub-regional focal point countries including Jamaica. The training was intended to support emergency response preparedness and provided participants with an overview of the regional and in-country disaster response mechanisms; familiarization with the emergency response logistics equipment pre-positioned in the country; and the knowledge to set up the equipment when deployed during a disaster response. A total of 21 participants (of which 2 women) were trained.
2023 Narrative: Since 2018, WFP has partnered with CDEMA to strengthen logistics and supply chain management in the Caribbean to improve the delivery of assistance to vulnerable populations. As part of efforts to develop the regional supply management system, WFP is providing support to CDEMA for the testing and roll out of CDEMA's supply chain management system, the CDEMA Logistics System (CLS) in participating states. The CLS is a platform that allows national, regional, and international humanitarian actors to register and track logistics, food, and other assets that CDEMA can call on in an emergency and in November 2023, the system was rolled out in Jamaica. The rollout commenced with a CLS training course where 22 individuals (7 females and 15males) participated in the event. Participants gained proficiency in the use of the system and the training provided the platform for national-level stakeholders to collaborate on emergency relief management and distribution measures with ODPEM. A stock-taking exercise was subsequently undertaken to capture emergency stock in the CLS at one of the ODPEM warehouses. The integration and adoption of the system allows the government to modernize and digitize logistics operations in Jamaica, an important step in improving the capacity to respond on the ground in an emergency. With WFP support, ODPEM now has increased human resource capacities in logistics with the addition of a new Logistics Associate to the organization. The main role of the Logistics Associate includes, building logistics capacity in CDEMA as well as in the ODPEM, to assist with the roll-out of the CLS and advance the implementation of the regional emergency logistics strategy. WFP places significant emphasis on regional partnerships in alignment with Caribbean countries' commitment to regional integration and collaboration. As such, country's financial requirements and funding availability reflect also regional contributions implemented by WFP through its partnerships with regional institutions including CDEMA, CARICOM and/or OECS amongst others.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Resilience to Climate Change and Sustainable Natural Resource Management
Outcome: Caribbean people, communities, and institutions enhance their adaptive capacity for inclusive, gender responsive DRM and climate change adaptation and mitigation
Output: MSDCF 5.3:  Populations impacted by shocks and disasters receive assistance in order to meet essential needs, protect livelihoods and preserve their nutrition status
Sub-Output: JAM: Affected populations in Jamaica  benefit from strengthened systems to deliver food, voucher and cash assistance
Description: WFP will assist shock-affected populations with cash-based transfers or food in-kind in response to events necessitating international assistance. This outcome focuses on strengthening systems to meet food, nutrition, and other essential needs of shock-affected people.
Agencies: United Nations Global Pulse Asia Pacific (Global Pulse Lab); United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: European Commission Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations; Global Affairs Canada; United States Agency for International Development Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance; World Food Programme Multi-donor
Implementation partners: Jamaica Jamaica Ministry of Labour and Social Security
SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis; Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2022 Narrative: In partnership with the government of Jamaica, in 2022, WFP worked on strengthening national capacities for registration, delivery mechanisms, monitoring and reconciliation for food and cash assistance. Ahead of Tropical Storm Ian (which was later upgraded to a hurricane), WFP contributed 50 Samsung tablets to the Ministry of Labour and Social Security; the tablets were preloaded with digitalized JHDINA forms for beneficiary intake/registration for data collection among populations that may have been affected by the storm. The digitalization of data collection processes improves the speed at which decisions on assistance can be made thus better benefiting the impacted population.  WFP provided technical support for cash transfers through social protection in response to COVID-19, which included the first use of digital money for social assistance payments in Jamaica, using WiPay as a payments provider. WFP and the MLSS worked with WiPay to scale up cash out points and further reach people in areas without cash out points through utilization of a mobile unit. WFP further worked with MLSS and WiPay to create a tailored dashboard that could provide real-time data on cash out status for implementation of the intervention. This dashboard enabled tracking and following up to encourage people to cash out and troubleshoot any issues they were facing.
2023 Narrative: WFP‚Äôs work on capacity strengthening provides support to regional and national institutions to strengthen social protection systems to respond to shocks, ensuring that the immediate essential needs of the vulnerable can be met in times of crisis. WFP carries out activities to enhance social protection systems at the national level to increase their capacity to reduce poverty and vulnerability and provide assistance to shock-affected people.In partnership with the government of Jamaica, in 2023, WFP provided technical support to the government for the design and preparation of a cash-based transfer pilot to be implemented in late 2023 and early 2024. In 2023, specific assistance was provided for the creation of a digital beneficiary intake form for registration, development of requirements for a payment services provider, and development of eligibility criteria based on key vulnerabilities for the pilot. The eligibility criteria ‚Äì which was captured in a scorecard that can be developed and tailored in response to crises ‚Äì include but is not limited to household income level, eligibility for social assistance, number of dependents within a household, and the presence of chronic conditions and/or disability. Upon completion of the pilot, the government tested a number of fundamental components for provision of digital payments for social assistance, with significant focus on digitization of processes across the intervention. The implementation of the pilot is expected to inform future scale-up and utilization of digital payments for new or existing social assistance programmes, and provide support to vulnerable households.

2022 Narrative: In Jamaica, 26,557 people with ongoing food security needs ‚Äì primarily elderly and disabled or chronically ill households that did not receive assistance though the Programme of Advancement Through Health and Education (PATH) ‚Äì received digital cash assistance payments through WiPAY, a mobile payment service provider, after having received a unique ID number through text messages or through the parish social workers; cash assistance was then physically redeemed at a pay-out location or mobile unit in their respective parish. Through the Ministry of Labour and Social Security, WFP provided cash assistance as part of the national response to the COVID-19 pandemic specifically targeting the elderly many of whom were women, to meet their food and nutritional needs amid the ongoing food security within the region. After the use of the digital wallet with cash assistance, WiPay again contracted by the Government of Jamaica, demonstrating the relevance of this tool in the digital payments sphere. Building on this, WFP will continue supporting the Government in testing new payment modalities with a focus on addressing concerns with existing payment modalities such as cost, convenience, timeliness, responsiveness and accessibility issues; considering upgrading payment delivery mechanisms as part of wider efforts for more resilience and shock-responsive social protection systems; and exploring more user-centric payment modalities that lead to financial inclusion, promote savings and result in greater empowerment of women and vulnerable people.
2023 Narrative: Implementation status: not activated in 2023

Sub-Output: JAM: Jamaica government benefits from strengthened food systems in order to increase access to affordable and nutritious food for food insecure populations.

Implementation partners: Jamaica Jamaica Ministry of Labour and Social Security

QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Data Collection and Analysis
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2022 Narrative: "In 2022, WFP provided technical assistance on school feeding following the Government‚Äôs interest in exploring the potential for collaboration with and support from WFP for its national school feeding programme. WFP carried out a one-week scoping mission in Jamaica with the intent to assess the status of school feeding in the country, with an emphasis on key issues and gaps that the organization can help address. Specifically, the Government requested support in analyzing challenges including in programme design, logistics and procurement systems, digitalization, monitoring and accountability. WFP has developed a roadmap for technical assistance for government consideration as a follow up to the mission. WFP also facilitated and supported the Government of Jamaica's participation in the IX Latin America and Caribbean Regional School Feeding Forum in Colombia in April 2022. The Forum offered an opportunity for the Jamaican delegation - led by Honourable Minister Fayval Williams - to exchange information and best practices with countries across the region for the improvement of the national school feeding programme in Jamaica, and to further learn about several options to help with digitalizing certain aspects of school feeding design and implementation. In 2022, WFP in partnership with CARICOM undertook two rounds of data collection on the state of food security, livelihoods and access to markets related to COVID-19 and the global food price crisis within the region. The most recent data was collected in August 2022. Results from this survey provided insights into food security and disruption of livelihoods. The latest edition of the report included an analysis of cost-of-living impacts including a special focus on farming and fishing livelihoods. One regional summary report along with an updated interactive dashboard was produced. "
2023 Narrative: In May 2023, WFP administered the sixth round of the food security and livelihoods survey on behalf of CARICOM. The survey results revealed that 3.7 million out of 7.1 million people, or 52 percent of the population of the English-speaking Caribbean, remain food insecure. While this is a 10 percent decrease when compared to an August 2022 survey, the results highlighted growing financial hardship and challenges due to the rising cost of living, in the aftermath of the pandemic. The surveys continue to play a critical role in informing analysis and decision-making for governments and development partners in the region and have significantly contributed to the current prioritization of the food security agenda. In August 2023, WFP published a country-specific Food Security and Livelihood Survey summary for Jamaica. According to the report, people continue to experience challenges to their livelihoods due to the current cost of living crisis. Most respondents to the survey reported significant price increases in food, housing, gas, health and fuels and food consumption patterns show challenges with food security in the country. https://www.wfp.org/publications/caribbean-food-security-livelihoods-survey-may-2023 .ÔªøGiven the Government of Jamaica‚Äôs interest in improving the delivery of the national school meals programme, WFP also facilitated the participation of the Government of Jamaica in ‚ÄòThe Power of Multi-Sector Approaches for Human Capital Development‚Äù event which was held in Brazil in August 2022. The event aimed to chart out pathways to strengthen human capital in the region so that every person can reach their full potential. The Forum offered an opportunity for representatives from across the region to boost multi-sector approaches linking education, food security and nutrition for human capital development via school feeding and social protection systems.
2024 Narrative: Enhancing National School FeedingSchool Feeding Programmes remains a cornerstone of Jamaica‚Äôs efforts to combat food insecurity, particularly among vulnerable children. WFP continued to provide technical assistance to the Government of Jamaica to improve the delivery, quality, and coverage of this programme. This support aims to ensure that children across Jamaica have consistent access to nutritious meals, essential for their growth and academic success. A significant milestone in 2024 was the launch of a three-year Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) Joint Programme for Digital Transformation in collaboration with UN partners, including the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO), the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO), and the United Nations Children‚Äôs Fund (UNICEF). Under this initiative, WFP is partnering with the Ministry of Education, Skills, Youth and Information to support efforts to modernise and digitise major components of the school feeding programme. This will include efforts to:1. Strengthen Data and Information Management: Enhanced data systems allow for real-time monitoring and evaluation of the programme‚Äôs reach and impact, ensuring accountability and identifying areas for improvement.2. Optimise Supply Chains: Assessing and streamlining supply chain operations may improve efficiency, reduce costs, and minimise waste, enabling more resources to be directed toward feeding children.3. Implement a Menu Creation Platform: A digital platform for designing cost-effective, nutritionally balanced school meal menus is to be introduced. This tool will empower schools to provide healthier meals that meet the dietary needs of students while maximising available resources.Data-Driven Insights for Food Security and LivelihoodsIn May, WFP launched the seventh round of the Food Security and Livelihoods (FSL) survey. The survey provided critical insights into regional and national food security dynamics, highlighting both progress and persistent challenges.Key Analytical Insights from the FSL Survey from a Caribbean-wide perspective:1. Reduction in Food Insecurity: The survey reported a 17% decline in food insecurity levels compared to 2023, signaling that strategic interventions are beginning to yield results.2. Persistent Challenges: Despite these improvements, approximately three million individuals‚Äî78% more than pre-pandemic levels‚Äîcontinue to experience moderate to severe food insecurity, highlighting the lingering impact of systemic shocks, including the COVID-19 pandemic.3. Vulnerability Hotspots: Low-income households, individuals with disabilities, and those with chronic illnesses remain disproportionately affected. Alarmingly, one-third of respondents reported low resilience to natural hazards, emphasising the need for targeted interventions in these communities.These findings present a nuanced understanding of the state of food systems in the Caribbean, enabling governments and partners to identify priority areas for intervention. To further enhance efforts at policymaking in food security and livelihoods, WFP published a country-specific Food Security and Livelihood Survey summary for Jamaica. The results reveal that, while the percentage of respondents struggling with high livelihood-related costs decreased from 61% to 44% between May 2023 and April 2024, these costs remain a significant concern. Despite a slight decline in inflation during early 2024, 58% of respondents reported significant food price increases in the three months before the survey. This localised report provides the government with actionable data to develop context-specific strategies, bridging gaps in food security systems and addressing the unique vulnerabilities of each Jamaica.

2024 Narrative: Human capacity development in the region is a critical component for an improved coordinated response to manage current and future emergencies. A major achievement in 2024 was the launch of a comprehensive eLearning course in Emergency Logistics for disaster management professionals in the Caribbean, including Guyana. This self-paced course features nine modules, covering critical areas of supply chain management, including warehouse management, transport operations, procurement and sourcing, customs, and forwarding. The course is designed with thoughtful illustrations that reflect the unique logistics environment of the Caribbean, making it both accessible and relevant to professionals in Guyana to increase national surge capacity for disaster response. WFP also strengthened its partnership with the Guyana Civil Defense Force, focusing on collaborative strategies to improve disaster risk management. Through engagement with the Civil Defence Commission (CDC), WFP identified key areas for potential collaboration, particularly around challenges the CDC faces in implementing disaster response efforts. The partnership highlighted critical focus areas, including training in early warning systems, cross-sector partnerships, logistics optimization, and resource distribution, all essential for boosting disaster resilience in Guyana. This collaboration underscores WFP‚Äôs proactive approach in building capacity, fostering coordination, and enhancing the nation‚Äôs preparedness for climate-related emergencies

2022 Narrative: COVID-19 and the war in Ukraine had significant impacts on households throughout Guyana. The rising cost of living has increased food insecurity, as it has across the Caribbean, with access to markets for many households becoming more of a challenge due to affordability. The Government of Guyana has been expanding social assistance programmes to address the needs of the most vulnerable and poorest households to both address immediate needs, but also to empower people ‚Äì particularly women. Through the MSDCF, UN Agencies have supported the MHSSS to strengthen social protection systems and programmes. Amongst other areas of support, the Spotlight Initiative emphasizes the strengthening of the social protection framework that addresses economic, social and other vulnerabilities, including gender based violence through the leadership of UN Women. UNICEF has supported the creation of a plan for social workforce development. WFP has partnered with the MHSSS to provide additional support to the most vulnerable beneficiaries of the Women‚Äôs Innovation  Investment Network (WINN) programme. WIIN is designed to empower women and girls to become financially independent and WINN in Business Workshops provide tailored support to entrepreneurs. Support on digitalizing processes and systems for greater efficiency, improving data management and visualization for decision making, and expanding linkages with the hinterlands are all being supported under the leadership of the MHSSS. The work of the United Nations lends technical assistance to the ministry to further strengthen a variety of social protection programmes that address the needs of the most vulnerable, and provide opportunities for their empowerment.
2023 Narrative: The Government of Guyana, as part of its efforts to make school meals programmes more efficient, welcomed WFP‚Äôs support. The Guyana Ministry of Education, WFP and FAO conducted a scoping mission, including a desktop assessment to guide the work of the Ministry of Education in the development of a nutrition-sensitive, locally sourced menu for schools for the implementation of a homegrown school feeding programme. WFP also facilitated and supported the Government of Guyana to participate in ‚ÄòThe Power of Multi-Sector Approaches for Human Capital Development‚Äù event which was held in Brazil in August 2022. The forum aimed to chart out pathways to strengthen human capital in the region so that every person can reach their full potential. The event offered an opportunity for representatives from across the region to boost multi-sector approaches linking education, food security and nutrition for human capital development, using two complementary approaches: school feeding and social protection systems.To continue to monitor food security and livelihoods, CARICOM and WFP completed a sixth round of the food security and livelihoods survey. The survey results revealed that 3.7 million out of 7.1 million people, or 52 percent of the population of the English-speaking Caribbean, remain food insecure. While this is a 10 percent decrease when compared to an August 2022 survey, the results highlighted growing financial hardship and challenges due to the rising cost of living in the aftermath of the pandemic. The surveys continue to play a critical role in informing analysis and decision-making for governments and development partners in the region and have significantly contributed to the current prioritization of the food security agenda. In August 2023, WFP published a country-specific Food Security and Livelihood Survey summary for Guyana. According to the report, people continue to experience challenges to their livelihoods due to the current cost of living crisis. Most respondents to the survey reported significant price increases in food, housing, gas, health and fuels and food consumption patterns show challenges with food security in the country. https://www.wfp.org/publications/caribbean-food-security-livelihoods-survey-may-2023

2024 Narrative: In 2024, WFP continued to partner with the Government of Guyana to in enhance the efficiency of school meal Programmes through its partnership with the FAO. Working closely with the Ministries of Education and Agriculture, WFP focused on enhancing community-based school feeding initiatives by linking local farmers to school supply chains. This initiative aims to provide nutritious, locally sourced meals for students while strengthening local agricultural systems. Key milestones during the year included finalizing the project‚Äôs pilot and conducting scoping missions, which assessed current community-based school feeding activities through focus group discussions and interviews with stakeholders such as farmers, school administrators, and school feeding committees. The assessment identified strengths, challenges, and opportunities for integrating more local produce into school menus.As part of these efforts, a two-day workshop was held in partnership with the National Agricultural Research and Extension Institute (NAREI), where 28 farmers (22 women and 6 men) in Wauna, Region One, were trained in climate-smart agriculture, nursery management, cost of production, contract farming, and crop husbandry. A similar workshop was conducted in Nappi, Region Nine, benefitting 47 farmers (25 females and 22 males). These capacity-building workshops were aimed at equipping local farmers with the capacity to sustainably support the school feeding program in their communities. Another key achievement was WFP‚Äôs demonstration of the School Menu Planner (SMP) PLUS tool for the Ministry of Education, which expressed strong interest in integrating SMP PLUS into the national school feeding program. WFP is now working with the Ministry to develop a training concept and rollout plan for SMP PLUS.For 2025, WFP will focus on finalizing the school feeding project by implementing training for participating schools to enhance menu diversity and local food inclusion. WFP will also assess training effectiveness, make necessary adjustments, and develop a comprehensive implementation plan for SMP PLUS with detailed technical requirements and timelines.In line with its ongoing efforts to strengthen vulnerability analysis and address gaps in data management for stronger food systems and greater shock response. WFP completed the 7th round of the Food Security and Livelihoods survey in May 2024. Findings showed that while food insecurity decreased by 17 percent compared to the previous year, approximately three million people still face moderate to severe food insecurity, a figure 78 percent higher than pre-pandemic levels in 2020. The survey underscored that the most vulnerable groups, including low-income households and individuals with disabilities or chronic illnesses, remain disproportionately affected, with nearly one-third of respondents reporting low resilience to natural hazards. Specific to Guyana, WFP published a country-specific Food Security and Livelihood Survey summary for the country. According to the report, high cost of livelihood inputs continues to be the main contributor for disrupting livelihoods in the country, as reported by 70 percent of respondents. Households in Guyana continue to rely on negative coping strategies to meet their immediate food needs and food consumption patterns have shown very slight improvements.

2022 Narrative: WFP assisted shock-affected populations in Belize through the provision of cash assistance in 2022 in response to the impact of Hurricane Lisa in Belize in partnership with the Ministry of Human Development, Families and Indigenous People‚Äôs Affairs. Direct cash assistance at a total value of US$ 192,250 was provided to 6,461 identified people to meet immediate nutritional and other essential needs in the poorest areas most affected by the hurricane. Vulnerable persons received cash transfers on top of in-kind support from the ministry through DigiWallet, a digital payment solution in Belize. The use of digital payments provided greater options for cashing out or utilizing assistance and also proved to be significantly faster in reaching recipients, compared to other digital solutions utilized in the past.
2023 Narrative: Main results:Continuing from the cash assistance support as part of a shock-responsive social protection approach to meet food and other needs carried out in 2022, in 2023 WFP continued to assist shock-affected populations through the provision of cash bashed transfers and voucher assistance in response to the impact of Hurricane Lisa. In partnership with the Ministry of Human Development, Families and Indigenous People‚Äôs Affairs WFP launched the Hurricane Lisa Assistance Program (HLAP) in February and provided 2,119 individuals with cash assistance to meet their food and essential needs. A second programme was launched in July with the Ministry of Agriculture, Food Security  Enterprise to assist smallholder farmers who were impacted by the hurricane but previously excluded from the first programme. Under the Hurricane Lisa Recovery Assistance Program (HLRAP) a total of 2,959 smallholder farmers and their families received a total of BZD 1,000 through a digital mobile wallet. This contribution had a voucher allocation where farmers could purchase critical inputs for their farms, along with a BZD 300 cash allocation to meet any additional food and other needs for farmers and their families. This response built on previous engagement to strengthen social protection to be more shock responsive, and the use of digital money provided greater options for cashing out or utilizing assistance and proved to be significantly faster in reaching recipients, compared to other digital solutions utilized in the past.  Lessons learned:(1)   Timing of support for relief and recovery are key in achieving the goal/s of cash-based transfers. HLAP for relief assistance arrived timely (within 1 month after the hurricane), however, assistance for the recovery of farmers‚Äô livelihoods came 6-8 months after the hurricane. While beneficiaries are grateful for the assistance, many affected farmers have already lost several months of income (others lost faith in the Government‚Äôs support). (2)   To ensure timeliness and effectiveness of support, cash and digital payment solutions need to be formally adopted widely in Government as mechanisms deliver social assistance to the most vulnerable groups whenever the context is appropriate.

2022 Narrative: A web-based portal/ platform was developed to contribute significantly to the implementation of the Regional Food and Nutrition Security Policy while at the same time strengthen the CARICOM Action Committee on Food and Nutrition Security Platform. The web tool  is a game changer and will allow for real time analysis on the Food and Nutrition status of the Region. Support has been provided for the formulation of a TCP and implementation of a Joint United Nations initiative. The TCP will analyze the cost and affordability of a healthy diet (CoAHD) as well as the implement FIES methodology in the Caribbean. While the UNJP will address the urgent needs to assist countries with comprehensively understanding the range of impacts of the on-going crisis on agriculture and livelihoods, and in monitoring the drivers behind them. Overall result progress: 35%
